[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is that good?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I live at 146 Pine Ridge Road.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Good evening, members of the City Council Governance Committee, Chair Tseng, fellow members of the Charter Review Committee, and Medford community members.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: As you know, I served on the school committee for 32 years.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I asked to be appointed to the Charter Review Committee when I realized there was no one with school committee experience on the Charter Review Committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: While some of my former school committee colleagues may not agree with what we have put forth in the draft,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: that you are reviewing tonight, rest assured that it has been put forth with deep reflection, not only my own, but with the very diligent subcommittee and the entire Charter Review Committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: As someone who served with three different mayors, I strongly advocated for the mayor, whoever it might be, to remain as the school committee chair because the advantages are so strong.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: As a school committee member, I had access to the mayor at every meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Not just me, every school committee member had the advantage of being able to discuss key educational issues in front of the mayor.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: being present at the school committee meetings ensures that the mayor is familiar with all the issues in detail and has buy-in.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Our charter subcommittee interviewed all three mayors and each underscored how important it has been or is for them to fully comprehend school committee issues, our school issues, especially given the significant percentage of the budget which is spent on education.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I remember the frustration of my colleagues across the aisle, that is you, the city council members, in former years when mayors did not come before them.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You never heard that from school committee members.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We worked closely with the mayors and they had buy-in.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: To my former colleagues eager to do away with the role of the mayor as the chair of the school committee, I can only say be careful what you ask for.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: School committee members play a very vital role in supporting all students and education, and that is enhanced when the mayor who recommends the budget is not distanced from the intricacy of the issues that become before the committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Remember, the mayor only gets one vote, not more, not less, than any other member.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Later, I hope to perhaps address some of the other issues.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I wanted to address this issue of the autonomy of the school committee to pick their own officers or how that's done.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I will tell you that this comes from my long years of experience.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And one of the things that I understand is that power is just so sweet.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And if you would, I have seen that selection process happen.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I have seen very, very good people

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: who then decided they wanted to keep on being and locking out other members from getting an opportunity.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think it's important that members of the body have an opportunity to be either, which now would be the chair and secretary.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So if you would, that part of this comes from trying not to prevent fiefdoms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Now, in the original charter, when I went to look at it, there was practically nothing about the school committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And in this charter, there's not as much as I would like, quite honestly, because at the recommendation of the Collins Center, quite a bit was taken out that we had talked about.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: While I certainly understand the argument of having the body be autonomous and make their own decisions, I've also seen the negative.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we have to look at both positions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Now we're talking about chair and secretary.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Now the secretary role includes signing the bills on behalf of the school committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That is the current structure that we use in Medford is the secretary of the school committee signs the bills.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And once upon a time, I signed the bills for 10 years in a row.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It is a damn good thing that I'm honest, because nobody should have ever possibly wanted me to sign the bills for 10 years in a row.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And of course, I definitely invited my colleagues in and said, please take a look at what I'm doing, because I want to make sure that somebody else has eyes on this besides me.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It is not always a popular position because it takes time, but there is also an added stipend.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And there are added stipends for the position of what used to be vice chair and secretary.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And in fact, I saw the recommendations that I think Councilor Bears put out.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's significant money.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think it was like an $8,000 stipend for these positions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I am wanting members to have the opportunity to do these different roles and not just keep it so that one person develops power and fiefdom.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Now, if you read it, a key word is consecutive.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I didn't say you can only do it once when we wrote this language and you don't get to do it again.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I just said you can't do it consecutively.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So you can do it in, you could be the chair in year one, year three, year five.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You could be the secretary then.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You could alternate those two.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So it's far from perfect, but I think it's better than not saying anything at all.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So that is the thinking behind it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That is the rationale as we spoke on the committee of saying, look, do we put this in now personally, and maybe it's my mistake because I didn't catch it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But I didn't think about it, I have experience as a school committee member, not as a city Councilor.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Because quite honestly, I think you guys ought to rotate your chair, too.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I don't like the idea of having one person be the chair every single year.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'd much rather see it rotate around members.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that isn't to say that I don't want to see Council Bears not be the chair.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: at all.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm happy if he's chair one, three and five or whatever.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You get my point.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I just don't think that one person in our city government should have a lock on these positions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think it's important to let other members have a chance to get the experience of leading and being in that role.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That's where it comes from.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay, I need to take a look because it was originally that's what our discussion was.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The intent of being is that it would just, you know, because every two years you've got different people on the committee anyway.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So there's change, you know, so, but the idea was that not one person wouldn't have a lock on it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I'll take a look.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Well then don't put anything in the jar.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I mean, you know, that's always a possibility.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Um, you know, the, I don't, I don't know.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: how else to go about it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I understand people don't necessarily agree with me, but some of those people may be the same people who have a lock on positions now.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I don't know if that's true or not.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I don't want that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But I'm just saying that for me, I am looking at not creating fiefdoms of power.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm looking at ways of giving other members opportunities.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's pretty simple.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: To me, it's common sense.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Councilor Tseng, did you want me to go ahead to address that?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Well, I think we certainly considered all the different options.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We were concerned that not everybody, you know, if we looked over historically at where school committee members, what

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: uh wards they had lived in and we we were concerned in and and the way that our particular uh city there um we don't have a school in each ward so we were looking at school placements and how that worked and it it doesn't really correspond in any way and we were concerned i mean um

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Sometimes there aren't that many people interested in running for school committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's a very taxing job.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It takes a long time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: In the past, the stipends were always considerably lower.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We don't want someone running for position just because they want to collect the stipend.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so after we discussed all of the different options, and then we started trying to say, well, if we were doing ward representation, what would happen if we had wards where no one wanted to be on the school committee?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we were concerned about that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You know, after many different looking at this, this to us seemed to be an opportunity to certainly increase representation from different districts in the city, but also minimize other potential problems.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Right.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There we go, thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Councilor Tseng, I just wanted to come back for just a second to say I became a little nervous as I was listening to the discussion that all of a sudden the comparison was to what the school committee subcommittee proposed.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: in our particular part of the school committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And it is different than what was proposed for city Councilors.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That was because we did see that there was different roles and really in some ways different populations.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I wanted to say that I came slowly toward representation, but ultimately voted and supported it because as a member of the committee, and having attended many of the information sessions,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and listening to people and talking to people in other communities, as well as having the discussions that we'll talk more about in terms specifically about the school committee, I heard from our citizens a great interest in having ward representation.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think, and as I served on the committee, you know, you could go nuts doing this because there's always one more thing you can do and one more thing and make it better.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I absolutely believe that we're really all interested here in trying to come up with a good, positive solution.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we all understand that it's really time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So there's, you know,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: the weighing between how much do we go back to the drawing board and do another something and another something and how much we move is, you know, the question is there.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I just want to let the committee know that I came to appreciate ward representation, even though as someone who had ran and served our city for a long time, I loved representing the whole city, but there was much to be said for those other discussions and I don't want

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: the fact that we chose something different to put forward to you for the school committee to hamper the discussion or make anybody think that I was not a proponent for what the committee put forth overall.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I'm here tonight and I've lost Melanie.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So on behalf of Melanie McLaughlin, and also former school committee members, Sharon Hayes, Mia Masone, and Kathy Kreatz, we're all here tonight with you, Superintendent, to thank you and to say,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: give you our profound thanks for the seven years that you've given to Medford.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And, you know, I was on the committee when you joined us in a rather difficult time, and it was so wonderful to have your enthusiasm and your joy and the sense of pride in Medford and in our students and just excitement.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Former athletic coach, and some of you will know who I'm talking about, but it was quite a long time ago, the late Bud Kelly used to say that he'd always be talking about Medford pride, and he'd say, he'd pull up a shirt and he had drawn blue and white on his arm and said that Medford pride runs in his veins.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And to you, superintendent,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Medford pride runs in your veins.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so we are very thankful for the time that you have been with us.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So we are here tonight to thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It seems like it went so fast, but we so appreciate your dedication, the gifts you have brought to Medford, the gifts that you are leaving with us, and that we are better for you having been here.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So thank you so very much, Marice.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Come on, that's fine.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yeah.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I have to look around.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I think I got them all.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Did I get them all?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I got them all.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Anyway, what we've been very quietly doing for the last eight, maybe nine years is giving away money.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And of course it always amuses me that we have to come and ask you to accept it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This amused me when I was sitting over there, because I would think you'd be so happy to take it you would just.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: grab it from my hands and no need for formal approval but I'm here to give you $8,755 tonight to go towards the grants that teachers applied for so they we have a process where they write us their good ideas and

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We weigh and deliberate over them.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Very often, we can't fund all of them.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We received more than $26,000 in requests, just to give you some idea.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So roughly, right now, we're funding about a third of it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But last year, all together, we gave you over $16,000.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we're about on track for that this year.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And the type of grants that we love to fund is, for your like example, the middle school librarians joined forces and asked us to fund a community read.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we think that's a wonderful project to bring the middle school students together.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The Mississippi has asked us to fund, which we're partially funding, an author's visit.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They haven't had one for a very long time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: At the vocational school, they asked us for a brand new upgraded 3D printer.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and a much more expensive one than they've had, and we funded that at your last meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You okayed a field trip experience for the United Nations Club, and we're giving them $1,000 towards that trip.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We have an after-school cooking club at the Andrews.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We think it's a great idea.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: working on international food.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so we're funding some of their expenses.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So that's the thing we do.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They're not earth shattering, but they sure are fun.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we think that they add to a student's enjoyment.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we know from the feedback that we get that the teachers really present, appreciate having another funding source that they can ask to for money.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: One of the funds we just gave out was for 50 bucks.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And a teacher said, boy, really appreciate that very small amount of money, but that's something we can do and something which, frankly, I know that doesn't always happen on your end because it's a different thing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So anyway, we are very, very grateful to the people who support us.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Needham Bank has been a great supporter of us, giving us over $5,000 for the last couple of years.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The Medford Community Fund has also contributed to us for several years running after we've written for grants.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we're really an intermediary.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We collect money and we give it away.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you for joining us.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm going to do a roll call of attendance.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Our first item is approval not required for review, seven grant F. I'm going to invite the proponent to present their plans for the log division.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But first, if the city can actually set us up with this, and then the proponent can go ahead and continue.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So approval not required as reviewed by the board, we are to make sure that it meets certain criteria in which one of the criteria it does not meet as of yet.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is that my current correct understanding?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's Heidi Cabral.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Are there any questions from the board at this time?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So, based on the presentation by Attorney Cabral and Planner Evans has stated that it meets minimum percentage.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There is adequacy.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: of the right of way, and as of right now, there's vital access to the lots provided by Parkin.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So it meets all of the board's criteria.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I will put forth a motion to approve 7-Grant-F for approval not required, or to recommend, is it adopt?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Endorse.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So you'll endorse the plan as approval not required.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Endorse the plan.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Approval is not required.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A second.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: PM via Zoom, relative to an application by Herb Chambers, 400 Mystic LLC, 400 Mystic Avenue LLC for site plan review to permit the construction of a new three-story structure to replace the existing three-story structure, renovation of the existing five-story structure, along with the modifications of existing parking, vehicle circulation, landscape, and utilities associated with proposed Herb Chambers-Toyota-Boston

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay, so the next item on our agenda for this evening is zoning amendments.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I believe there was a city council paper number 24-033 where they refer it to us for this evening.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I will read the public hearing notice.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The Medford Community Development Board shall conduct a public hearing on June 5th, 2024 at 6.30 PM via Zoom.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: remote video conferencing relative to the following proposed amendments to the City of Medford zoning ordinance.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: One, amending the format of the table of use and parking regulations to replace the parking and loading code columns with specific parking and loading requirements.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Amending section 94-12, which is definitions, to add new defined terms and revise existing definitions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Number three, adopt a new GIS-based digital zoning map.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Adoption of the new map format is not intended to result in any material changes to the zoning of any parcels within the city, but is intended to confirm the best information available to the city regarding the existing zoning destination for all properties in the city.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Number four, amending sections 94.1-4, 94.6.3-3,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: section 2, 9411.7.2, section 4, and 94-12, to exempt municipal uses from certain use parking and dimensional requirements.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A link to the public hearing is posted on the city's website at medford.ma.org.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that's looking at the social economic community needs, traffic flow and safety, adequacy of utilities and public services, compatibility with the size, scale and design of other structures in the neighborhood, impacts on the natural environment, and the proposal's compatibility with the purposes of the city's comprehensive plan.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Medford, Massachusetts, 02155.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Danielle, can you please manage the public comment queue and read any previously sent emails or letters?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And to remind the board, I remember we were mostly in agreement, but due to the technical error, we were not able to vote at the last meeting, but we said that if the proponent came back, we would be willing to approve with a couple of conditions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Condition one being to remove the barbed wire on the fence.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: maintain screening on the fence to ensure parking is not visible from the public way.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The proponent was actually amenable to that condition.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Condition two, prior to applying for a sign permit, the applicant must submit plans to planning staff for review approval.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Preferred signage type would be downcast lighting, such as gooseneck, or halo-lit channel letters.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I believe the proponent was amenable to that as well.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Condition number three, strike parking, the same.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I believe, I'm not sure that we have to go over the benefits of this, making sure that the benefits outweigh any adverse effects as we've done that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So at this point, I'm not sure if the board has any further questions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Let's begin with some obligatory procedural matters.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This hearing of the Medford Community Development Board is being conducted via remote means.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings as provided for in Chapter 2 of the Acts of 2023.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The reminder that anyone who would like to listen to or view this meeting while in progress may do so by accessing the link that was included on the meeting agenda posted on the city of Medford's website.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If despite our best efforts, we are unable to provide real-time access, we will post a recording of this meeting on the city's website as soon as possible.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A reminder that given the remote nature of this meeting, tonight all votes from the board will be made by roll call.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Please also know that the project materials for all projects before the board can be viewed on the city's website as well.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The next item, I believe, let's see.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The next item is 4864 Commercial Street, which is a site plan review to construct a two-story, 97,857 square foot research and testing laboratory.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm going to read the public hearing notice.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The Metro Community Development Board shall conduct a meeting on March 20, 2024, after 6.30 p.m., via Zoom, remote video conferencing relative to an application for site plan review for a new non-residential structure of more than 10,000 square feet, which is a major project.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It was submitted by Empire Management Corporation of 171 Great Road, Akinas.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The applicant is seeking to demolish the existing structures, a construction staging yard, 48 Commercial Street, and a vacant industrial building, 64 Commercial Street, and construct a two-story, 97,857-square-foot research and testing laboratory, which is in allowed use in an industrial zoning district at 48 to 64 Commercial Street, Medford Mass 02155.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Our board is the site plan review authority per section 11-7.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: PDS staff, can you make any introductory comments, please?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So to make sure here, the board would definitely need to see final plans to vote going forward.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We can open up the public hearing this evening to hear the applicant, but we would be voting on final plans since there's some back and forth with the city, correct?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I think that's what we need to be clear of, because when it's conditioned to the point of change, then that means we should have a final set that we're voting on.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: OK, we'll hear it going forward.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I believe the tiny dash, you could go ahead.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Welcome to tonight's meeting of the Metro Community Development Board.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'll call the meeting to order.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Let's begin with some obligatory procedural matters.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This hearing of the Medford Community Development Board is being conducted via remote means.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings as provided for in Chapter 2 of the Acts of 2023.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A reminder that anyone who would like to listen to or view this meeting while in progress may do so by accessing the link that was included on the meeting agenda posted on the City of Medford's website.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If, despite the best efforts, we are not able to provide real-time access, we will post a recording of this meeting on the city's website as soon as possible.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A reminder that given the remote nature of the meeting, tonight all votes from the board will be made by roll call.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Please also know that project materials for all projects before the board can be viewed on the city's website, and that's visiting medfordma.org, and you can click on current city board filings.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Alicia will provide a link in the chat.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm going to do roll call attendance for the board.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Vice Chair Emily Hederman.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Present.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Peter Cowles.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's muted.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Just put a thumb up, Peter.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay, so the first item on the board, for the board to review tonight is 96-100 Winchester Street.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's a PDD, which is planned, PDD special permit site plan and special permit.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So the CDB, the advisory to the city council will only be voting on a recommendation tonight.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I'm going to summarize the public hearing and the public meet and legal ad.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The Medford Community Development Board shall conduct a public meeting on February 21st, 2024 after 6.30 p.m.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: via Zoom to make a recommendation to City Council relative to an application by 96-102 Winchester Street, LLC for a planned development district special permit.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and site plan review to permit the construction of a four-story, 65-unit residential building and a 4,000-square-foot commercial structure at the site known as 100 Winchester Street, comprised of properties located at 96 to 100 Winchester Street, Myford Bluffs, 02155.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A public hearing will also be later held by the Medford City Council on March 12, 2024 at 7 p.m.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: in the Medford City Council Chamber on the second floor of Medford City Hall at 85 George P. Hassett Drive.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The Zoom link to the public hearing will be posted no later than 48 hours prior to that meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Does the staff have any opening comments for this project?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So the new PDD1 overlay sets.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: new dimensional regulations that align with the approved preliminary plan.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: In order to build the proposed development, they must now receive a plan development district special permit and site plan review approval from city council.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that's where we're at now.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I am going to invite the applicant to introduce themselves and to please present your proposal.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, please.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm trying to wrap my head around the mitigation that you were trying to explain for that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm trying to see what the level of service F had to do in regards to the mitigation that was suggested by the traffic engineer.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you for clarifying.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I just want to clarify my inquiry was that I understand that the no build scenario, but however, it's like, it's you create.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: no matter how many new cars you add to that intersection, it's still creating, it's adding to the instability of that breakneck point, right?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And it's like, just like if you were on, I don't know, intersection 495, whether you build something new, intersection 495 is going to always be unstable at a loss of F. And I just want to know what were the other scenarios that you would do to create mitigation for that?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Peter?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you, Peter.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, if needed.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Actually, I couldn't see anyone else.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I just wanted to make sure before I close the comment period.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: All right, so I'm going to close the comment period now and I'm going to bring it back to the board to see if there's any clarifying, again, any clarifying comments that you are looking for or want to deliberate on now, especially to discuss the criteria for approval under site plan review and the PD special permit and potential conditions for approval actually.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Alicia.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So before we can even go into this, we have to make sure that

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The site plan is actually in court.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: With the method zoning ordinance, the Community Development Board shall approve a site plan if the board finds that the site plan is consistent with the performance standards.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: for multiple dwellings or non-residential use described in section 6.4, and that the proposed development meets the standards listed in section 11.710.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I will not read out all of those.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: However, that's where we're pulling from.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So again, the standards for site plan review listed in section 11.7.10 of the zoning ordinance.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we're also looking for the criteria for approval for a special permit granting authority may approve the PDU special permit if the SPGA finds that all the following, that there are, I believe there are nine.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And Alicia, usually Danielle will put these on the screen for the public to see.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There are nine criteria that need to be met for the permit.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I'm not sure if you want to share those for the public or if we can just go over the conditions that need to be discussed and hashed out per the department heads prior to us even getting to that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So again, there's seven criteria under the site plan, and then there's about nine under the special permit granting agency.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And our due diligence would be to make sure that we, that the proponent in the project is covering all of them.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And based on city department head comments, if we were to approve this, there are conditions that would need to be met.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: specifically speaking, 41 conditions in total.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And the city at this point will highlight those conditions for us.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Or Alicia, would you like me to highlight them?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If you can specifically touch on the water, because that was one of, I had a question, but there's a condition that captures.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And then the city's coals drainage system.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Applicant shall update the plans to show the overflow pipes and connections, if any, to the city's coals drainage system.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That's number 17.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that will be a condition to get the stormwater permit, correct?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that would be a question, Attorney Baranski, for the proponent of Mr. Quinn.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you, Tony Boranski.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ari, did you have a further question?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And looking over the conditions, what is the board's temperature on even grant and approval tonight?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm not sure.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm not sure that we're able to get, are we going to continue this or is this something that you feel comfortable

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: with approving or suggesting, recommending for approval to the city council with so many things that are left open?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Peter, thank you for asking.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So hearing the city's stance on where they stand with these conditions, as well as the board, at least one board member, and the proponent being amenable to

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: adhering to these conditions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm looking for a motion to recommend approval with conditions of the plan development special permit and site plan review for 96 to 104 Winchester Street.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: the mitigation of sound and the city council was to come up with the condition.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Good evening, and welcome to tonight's meeting of the Medford Community Development Board.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'll call the meeting to order.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Let's begin with some obligatory procedural matters.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This hearing of the Medford Community Development Board is being conducted via remote means.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings as provided for in Chapter 2 of the Acts of 2023.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A reminder that anyone who would like to listen to or view this meeting while in process may do so by accessing the link that was provided on the meeting agenda posted on the City of Medford's website.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If despite our best efforts we are not able to provide real-time access, we will post a recording of this meeting on the City's website as soon as possible.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A reminder that given the remote nature of this meeting, tonight all votes from the board will be made by roll call.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Please also know that the project materials for all projects before the board can be viewed on the city's website, which is medfordma.org.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Danielle will provide the link in the chat.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm gonna do a roll call attendance for the board.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Starting with Ari Fishman.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Present.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Pam Marianski.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Present.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Sally Akiki.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Present.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And myself, Jackie McPherson.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We have absent members.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Our first item is Walkley Court PDE for special permit for site plan review as well as special permit review.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I will read the public hearing notice for it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The Method Community Development Board shall conduct a public hearing on February 7, 2016.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: 24, after 6.30 p.m.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: via Zoom remote video conferencing relative to an application for site plan review.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Submitted by the Medford Housing Authority for the demolition of all existing buildings on the site to be replaced by a mid-rise building with 198 apartments for elders and seniors and four buildings with 40 family units, 24 units in a low-rise building and 16 townhomes and three buildings.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The CDB board will also hold a public meeting relative to the application for plan development permit, special permit for the same matter.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A subsequent public hearing for the application of the plan development special permit on the same matter will be held by the Medford City Council on February 20th, 2024 at 7 p.m.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: in Medford City Council Chambers, which is located on the second floor of Medford City Hall.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Danielle, can you please introduce

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Anyone from the Medford Housing Authority?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you very much.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That's what we will be doing our due diligence this evening along with the public.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay, seeing none, I'm going to close the public comments portion and ask the board again if there's any other information that they want to have clarified.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: before deliberation?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you, Alicia.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I appreciate that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I've been remiss on the actual public comments, but I'm hoping that from your end, you can share that information.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: What is the legality of it?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Do you have to acknowledge it or read the entire?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is not to negate any kind of concerns or anything, but as far as not having enough space for a fire truck, I am sure at this point the fire chief would have

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: address that at this point.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I would look to the city to make sure that that was handled.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And then the traffic engineer for the traffic study has accepted the traffic study with conditions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: As far as the height, the whole idea of it being a zoning amendment was to accommodate the project for a path forward.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I'm not sure how to address the comments.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: going forward if they've been sufficiently covered.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You don't need to respond to them.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I just, I don't want the public to think that we're not taking their concerns into question, but I'm just trying to highlight that these are things that have been fully vetted and addressed by city officials and Method House and in their team.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yeah.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: At this point, I would, if Medford Housing or any of its representatives would like to touch upon any of the concerns that have been placed before them, they're more than welcome to.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I personally don't

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: find it necessary because it has been presented in detail.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And then following up with the conditions, I think that will cover most of the other concerns.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But I'm going to leave that up to my fellow.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So again, at this time, I am going to open up to the board again for clarifying comments and deliberation.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ari, I had seen your hand raised first.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Do you want to go ahead and speak, Ari?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, thank you, Daniel.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I was actually, my question was when I heard that there was not going to be a proposal in traffic mitigation, that's what I want to go back and want to know what the proponent had, if you had had a chance to read the department head comments, or if that was something that we were going to collectively do at the end with conditions, if there was approval.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But there are a significant amount of conditions that we'll have to go over prior to us being able to

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: approved site plan or recommend to the city council for a special permit at this point.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And hearing no other comments from the board, I do know, and based on my review and based on confirmation from the city, the plans have not changed based on what was adopted and recommended by the CDB board, by the city council previously.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So at this point, if we did want to approve, I'm guessing

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: we would be looking at the conditions as presented.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. Driscoll?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Even if you weren't there, you're just voting the minutes to be filed.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is that correct, Danielle?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's true.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But you can also abstain.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That's your right.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Aye.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But this all seems vaguely familiar.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So before I go on with the MEF, I first wanna assure you that there is life after school committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: once fellow school committee members and school committee elect.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So while I didn't get to serve with you, I'm certainly grateful to you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So thank you very much.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And to Mia, when I thought about you, there's one word that stands out for me.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Not blunt, but moral.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I remember in those first two years when we serve together, which there was some really difficult times, because, yeah, there were some difficult times in the other, you know, pandemic and everything, but there were some really difficult times, and you led.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: with a deep moral sense that I just really think was wonderful, because there was a lot of pressure.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I so appreciated that from you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And of course, with you, it's been a delight to meet all your family members, your husband Tim, to watch the kids grow.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that's one of the things that as we, you know, sometimes forget there's a real, when we're working together every week and over the years, you get to know everybody's family.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So anyway, congratulations to you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I know this has been a long time coming and I know you're going to enjoy it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And just in case you get bored now, you and I have already talked about it, but Kathy, you know, and Sharon, the Medford Educational Foundation is looking for more members and,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I'd like right now to invite you to join us because we have this fantastic little group of dedicated people.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Some of them are not here tonight, some of them I'll introduce.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But we've been working sort of behind the scenes for roughly seven years.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I actually have to go back and figure it out sometime.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The Medford Educational Foundation was started

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: way long ago, maybe 20 plus 25 years, by the late, great Bob Gilligan, attorney Bob Gilligan, and Gene Bralt, or Len Bralt, excuse me.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It lasted for a couple of years, and then it kind of went by the wayside.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ann Kasuth and I resurrected it about seven or eight years ago, and we've been working behind the scenes ever since that time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Today, tonight, on behalf of the Medford Educational Foundation, I am writing you to formally ask you to accept a donation to the Medford Public Schools to cover the specific grants that we are able to fund at this time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Each year, we have two times during the year where we accept applications from teachers, and we ask them either to apply for a grant of zero to $200

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: or another grant from $200 to $2,000.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we accept those grants.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And then as a body, we deliberate on the grants.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We check out with the schools that

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The projects are consistent with the educational values and direction that the school system must go in or is going in.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And Diane Caldwell, who of course you guys all know, has been extremely helpful in being a partner with us and volunteering her time so that we could make these grants.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This December, we received over 38 requests from teachers who outlined specific projects or requests that they believe would enhance their students' learning experience.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: While we would have loved to fund each and every one of them, we met as a group and decided which grants we could fund in their entirety, which grants we could partially fund, and sadly, which grants we couldn't afford at this time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The December application cycle yielded more than $24,000 in requests, and we have been able to fund $13,058.86.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So tonight, we're asking you to approve our donation, and I do want to mention that we've done this before but we haven't been asked to present it to you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But we also gave over $10,000 in the spring for example too.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: However, we would not be able to do the work we do with the support of our donors.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: we want to acknowledge the generosity of Needham Bank, and especially Vice President and Branch Manager, Jean Kalau, who presented us with a total donation of over $10,000 this year.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And... This is Jean.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Jean, stand up.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Jean.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This connection between us and Jean was because of Mia.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so we are extremely appreciative for that because it sure has helped this year.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: As you can see, our requests are steadily increasing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And in fact, it's, you know, we need more money.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We need more money, Jean.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So, and let's see, I wrote, the Medford Education Foundation has kept a low profile, but has been receiving, reviewing, and funding grants to teachers over the last seven years.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This coming year, we hope to share our good news more widely as we anticipate the need to raise more funds for the many requests we find ourselves receiving.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That is code for don't be surprised if you get a letter.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Good evening and welcome to tonight's meeting of the micro community development board.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'll call the meeting to order.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Let's begin with some regulatory procedure matters.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This hearing of the Mecca Community Development Board is being conducted via remote means.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings as provided for in Chapter 2 of the Acts of 2023.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A reminder that anyone who would like to listen to or review this meeting while in progress may do so by accessing the link that was included on the meeting agenda.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: posted on the city of Medford's website.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If despite our best efforts, we are not able to provide real-time access, we will post a recording of this meeting on the city's website as soon as possible.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A reminder that given the remote nature of this meeting tonight, all votes from the board will be made by roll call.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Please know that the project materials for all projects before the board can be viewed on the city's website at medfordma.org and by clicking on current city board filings.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Danielle will provide the link in the chat.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I will do a roll call attendance.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Awesome.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is a continued public hearing to consider and vote on our recommendations to city council regarding the zoning overlay to comply with the MBTA community zoning law.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: At the last meeting, the board members were supportive of the proposed overlay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: However, there was discussion regarding the appropriate parking minimums and maximums, such as reducing parking minimums to 0.5 spaces per unit or requiring no parking minimums at all.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We asked staff to model the unit capacity yields for the 0.5 spaces.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So the city has reported back.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Danielle, if you want to highlight that, and if the board wants to start deliberations from there.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I have the, is it the Downtown Trout Work Zoning Study?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is that the slides that Daniel shared?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Emily, do you have a question?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yeah, I

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I echo Emily, 1 of the things that I stand firm with, and I understand that the city has, you know, you take away park and even with transit oriented development, then you'll still see a spillover.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But at the same time, it's like the whole idea of it being compliant and dealing with the transit oriented is that we're trying to prioritize people.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: over cars.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I am all for the more housing units that we can get on a property, whether they're built or not, but removing that barrier and offering that incentive for a developer to take up if they so choose.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So that's where my stance is.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I don't know if there's any other questions that's leading up to us and what we need to do for recommendations.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And as far as maximum parking, I would say we definitely want to

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm all for bringing it down under the 1.5 maximum if needed, but I don't know how the board feels about that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is just picking up on what we were talking about at the previous meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I don't know if anyone had any comments on the maximum parking or if there's any other comments on the parking overall.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And also still definitely keeping in mind equity for people that actually really need to utilize those spaces, whether it's a disability or they're caring for someone or whatever the reason is, we're still allowing it there.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's not going into zero, but so we're making notice that, yeah, parking is needed, but again, minimal parking.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: All right, so, Danielle, I know that you wanted us to sort of give some feedback on developer incentives.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Did anyone have any further discussion on how you thought the incentives played out in the amendment?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Or any additional thoughts from what was captured at the last meeting?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Or if you wanted to add anything to Daniel's suggested or not suggested, but they're captured development incentive bonuses, or are you fine with how they are as is.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is the board ready to vote on a recommendation for the.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is it, it's the approval of the amendment for the zoning overlay to send to City Council or to recommend to City Council?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No, thank you, Director Hunt.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That's my oversight.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: for non-commercial greenhouse, tool shed, or similar assessment structure?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Did I get that right, Alicia?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It was originally 0.8.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So for myself, I'm not a transportation planner, but dealing in economic development and some of the things that I know that goes into the traffic engineering and everything that comes with developers and their incentives, I'm willing to keep it at 1.8 to keep it attractive, even though, I mean, I don't know how the board feels about going to 0.5 at this point.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we don't want the city to lose an economic development planner before they get them.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I guess am I?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm going to reiterate here.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so that's what I'm just trying.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I'm trying to stay out as much as the conversation as possible, because as you know, just what would be in my previous agency, well, now that we're separated, the whole idea of it being an MBTA rule is to eliminate parking minimum.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I'm trying not to be too heavy handed on my,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: my share and why I think it should be.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I prefer for the boards to deliberate and for us to get to an agreement of what the minimum parking is.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No, no, which is great.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I like I said, I just I allow you to go I it this is great for other members.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And it's even you know, great for the members of the audience, the public and even myself just to hear it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But I already know that I am sort of biased in where I sit, unfortunately.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yeah, I'm looking more at the maximums than I am at the minimums, but it looks like.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So we would be amending to so we were at this point.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We were asking for a vote to recommend just to get a little bit more of the boys temperature again.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: parking minimums around other transit areas in Medford?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yeah, I can go with either the 0.8 or 0.5 for minimums, but I'm definitely, my vote is for the 1.2 for maximum.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I guess we just have to come back to agreement because as of right now, we only have Ari and Peter that are saying 0.5 for minimums.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So we have to get that clear.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yeah, based on what he's already shared with us, I deduce that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: All right, Ari for minimum?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Sam?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So yeah, I'm the same for me for the minimums, either 0.8 to 0.5.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I definitely hear that, especially myself taking MBTA from where I sit, we're not at a point where Medford can just start dropping parking spaces.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But at the same time, even though I think I'm less than, I'm a little bit over half a mile, but

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: even I can get to Wellington station easily.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So the fact that this is like right there in the Wellington station area, that's not one of my biggest concerns, and I will stand by my 1.2 for maximum, but I can be swayed for 0.8, 0.5 for minimum.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So looking at that overall, if I was to change to 0.5 to keep it, it would be Peter, myself and Ari,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: have the same numbers as does PAM, so that's four.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That's voting for 0.5 minimum, 1.2 maximum to get it passed.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So in that case, we would be amending because it came in at 0.8.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So we're looking for a motion to recommend to city council that they approve the Wellington Station Multifamily Overlay District

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: with the amendments for 0.5.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's 0.5 minimum parking and 1.2 maximum.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And then add the Y to the use table.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is there a second?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'll do a roll call with.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I have Peter Cowles.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ari Fishman.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Pam Marionski.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Sally Akiki.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Myself, Jackie McPherson, I'm a yes, and we have one no, which is Sharad.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We didn't get your no.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Well, we've heard your no, Sharad, but I should have called you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: All right.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So we have five yeses for the recommendation to city council.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I have a motion to recommend to city council that they approved the Wellington station multifamily overlay district with the amendments to from 0.8 spaces from 0.5 spaces per dwelling to 0.8.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Well, there's 0.8.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: From 0.8 to 0.5, Jackie.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yeah.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Did you go from 0.5 to 0.8?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We're not keeping it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We're changing it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Sorry.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We're amending it from 0.8 to 0.5.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: OK.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And then we're also amending the maximum from 1.5 to 1.2.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And then we're adding a yes to the use table where it needs to be.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Do I have to spell that out?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That's based on my table.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's number 7 for non-commercial greenhouse to shed or similar accessory structure.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is that a sufficient motion or recommendation?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, we have five yeses and one abstention.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Tomorrow, okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we have the next item on the agenda is approval of minutes, but we have none.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So we'll go to the next item, which is miscellaneous and other updates.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And you're looking to get like members of the community as well for the steering committee?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So the role in zoning with the comprehensive plan, I'm trying to see how will this, because zoning is the land use like laws that inform the comprehensive plan that we just did with the steering committee, which I love being on.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So how will that change the comprehensive plan going forward?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Will it, it's going to have a huge.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So you need the zoning changes to actually implement the comprehensive plan as visioned?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I didn't realize we had so many regulatory changes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I guess I was so romanticized by the idea of having a collaborative vision of the community that I didn't realize.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And now we have to work backwards to make it happen.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I mean, I knew we had to, because obviously, being part of it, there were some things that just doesn't exist.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I didn't realize now we got to actually change the rules to match the plan.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Awesome.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you, Alicia.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think this is one of the longest shortest meetings ever.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I don't know who would initiate that, like, just send you an email and say, hey, this will be awesome.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Well, wait a minute, let's back up for the record.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Good evening and welcome to tonight's meeting of the Medford Community Development Board.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'll call the meeting to order.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Let's begin with some obligatory procedural matters.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This hearing of the Medford Community Development Board is being conducted via remote means.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings provided for in Chapter 2 of the Acts of 2023.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A reminder that anyone who would like to listen to or view this meeting while in progress may do so by accessing the link that was provided on the meeting agenda posted on the City of Medford's website.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If despite our best efforts, we are not able to provide real-time access, we will post a recording of this meeting on the city's website as soon as possible.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A reminder that given the remote nature of this meeting tonight, all votes from the board will be made by roll call.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Please know that the project materials for all projects before the board can be viewed on the city's website at medfordma.org and by clicking on current city board filings.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Danielle will provide the link in the chat.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm going to do a roll call attendance.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Sally Akiki.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Present.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Sharad Bajracharya.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Danielle, can you introduce any staff on the call?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay, so tonight, the city will present a zoning ordinance amendment to establish a new zoning overlay in the Wellington Station Multifamily Overlay District that would allow multifamily housing and mixed-use development as of right, and comply with Section 3A of MGL-40A, MBTA Community Zone 1.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I will read the public hearing announcement.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The Method Community Development Board shall conduct a public hearing on Wednesday, November 15, 2023, after 6.30 p.m.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: via Zoom.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: remote video conferencing relative to a proposed amendment to the City of Medford zoning ordinance and zoning map.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The purpose of the amendment is to comply with Section 3A of MGL 40A, which is also known as MBTA Community Zoning Law, by establishing a zoning overlay within a half-mile radius of the Wellington MBTA Orange Line Station that would allow multifamily housing and mixed-use development as of right.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The public may view and participate in this hearing by assessing the link included on the meeting agenda that will be posted on the City's website.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: no later than November 10th, 2023.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Questions and comments may be submitted via email at ocd-medford-ma.gov.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: For accommodations or aids, call 781-393-2480.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A subsequent public hearing on the same matter will be held by the Medford City Council on December 12th, 2023 at 7 p.m.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: in the Medford City Council Chamber.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: second floor of medford city hall 85 george p has to drive medford mass and via zoom a link to the public hearing will be posted no later than december 8 2023 again for accommodations or aids call 781-393-2425 a copy of the full text of the amendment is available in the office of the city clerk the office of planning development and sustainability and on the city's website

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay, so for, um, the city staff that's present, um, um, Danielle, you want to take the lead on the proposed ordinance?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'll stop sharing my screen for the moment.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Daniel, thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: One of the questions I wanted before you went through is, can you explain to the board and to the public exactly why this district was chosen and how it relates to, like for instance, why not West Medford?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Why not Medford Square?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Why is it at Wellington?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And Alicia, one of the things that I was hoping that can be illustrated here is myself as a planner and knowing more about the law, the MBTA law and how it is, I know, and just speaking with the city that moving it, moving it to another part of it, the city is not feasible with compliance.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But if you can paint out what that looks like for the audience, for the public and for the board.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So because this is one of the questions that I have, and I think one of the only other questions that I have,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And then I'll open it up for the board for clarification.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's the parking minimums.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Since we're doing this in a transit oriented development and we have 0.5 at this point, and we can actually really go big and create more density.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No parking minimums.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Get rid of them.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is that feasible?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is that something that

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And if I'm not mistaken, Danielle, you've ran the numbers.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Can you share with the board what that would mean if we were to get rid of the parking limit?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yeah, I guess I'm not sure if I'm alone in this one.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I understand your reservation on it, but we, our car dependency is the reason why we're in trouble with the house insurance now.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I just saw it as an opportunity just to not to be so car dependent, but I can also understand on the other side, because I happen to live in one of those apartment buildings near Homel that you just referenced.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is there any other board input on parking minimums or anything else?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Are there thoughts on the actual development incentive bonuses that Danielle wanted input on?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yeah, actually, that's a good point.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm so

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: against car dependency that one of the things that made it a little bit more humbling was I attended a conference where there was someone with a disability who had kept saying, you know, you keep talking about no parking, no parking, but what about my caretakers that come to take care of me?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: All right, so it's currently at 0.5, Danielle, or?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Where I live, if you have, you can have two spaces per unit.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And it's like, I don't know, there's different levels because we have a garage.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's not part, it becomes part of my rent if I take it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If I don't want any, if I want no parking, then it's not part of my rent.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I'm guessing that that's what the idea is.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No, thank you, Danielle, because one of the things, and it does seem, and we understand where the city's, I understand where the city's situation is, but it's also very,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'll call the meeting to order.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Let's begin with some regulatory procedural matters.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This hearing of the Medford Community Development Board is being conducted via remote means.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings as provided for in Chapter 22 of the Acts of 2023.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A reminder that anyone who would like to listen to or view this meeting in long progress may do so by accessing the link that was included.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: on the meeting agenda posted on the city of Medford's website.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If, despite our best efforts, we are not able to provide real-time access, we will post a recording of this meeting on the city's website as soon as possible.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A reminder that given the remote nature of this meeting tonight, all votes from the board will be made by roll call.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And you can click on current CD board filings.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Vice-chair Emily Hedeman.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Present.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Peter Kautz.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Let's see, Danielle, can you please introduce anyone from the staff?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So the first item on our agenda this evening after getting into order is a special permit drive-thru use for 3850 Mystic Valley Parkway, Bank of America.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's continued from 10-4-23.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The applicant is applying for a special permit for a bank drive-thru ATM at 3850 Mystic Valley Parkway, which is in the Meadowbrook Mall, aka Wegman Plaza, specifically the northerly service parking lot.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The special permit grant authority is the city council, and it has been referred to the city board for the board's recommendation on the matter.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The matter has been continued several times in order to redesign the site plan to satisfy planning staff and for sign on from other tenants on the shopping plaza.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm going to invite the applicant to introduce yourselves now, and you can present any updates on the proposal.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Danielle, have you provided screen sharing ability to all three of those members?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Jackie, you're on mute.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Sorry.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you so much for your presentation.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I appreciate it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We appreciate it at this time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We're going to ask if the city staff has any comments that they want to add.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I will open it up to the board and I want to remind the board that there are some conditions that have been set forth, recommended by the city for us to deliberate on as we go through.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We can either adopt, amend, disagree, or totally change them as you wish to go through.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm not sure if you've all had a chance to look at them.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But I will open it up for deliberation now from the board.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Any board members have questions on the conditions or clarifications?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: All right, hearing none, I'm going to open it up for public comment, just in case there's public comment.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If there's anyone that wants to speak from the public.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Those who wish to provide comments can use the raise hand feature, which places you in the line to be recognized and unmuted by staff.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Individuals may have up to two minutes to provide comments.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Before providing your comments, please state your name and address for the record.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You can also provide written comments via email.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: to ocd-ma.gov.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A reminder to all meeting participants to refrain from using the chat function to post or message comments as it is not part of the public record.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: However, if a participant is having audio or other technical difficulties, this may be entered into the chat to let myself and staff.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Danielle, can you please manage the public comment queue and acknowledge any previously sent emails or letters regarding this item?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And while we do that, I'm going to close the public comment.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So what would be the proper way to condition it so that it doesn't provide undue burden onto the proponent if it's something that we can't determine at this juncture now?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is the board okay with number five as written after hearing what has been presented by the city?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Good evening and welcome to tonight's meeting of the Medford Community Development Board.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'll call the meeting to order.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Let's begin with some obligatory procedural matters first.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm going to read the public hearing notice.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This hearing of the Medford Community Development Board is being conducted via remote means.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings as provided for in Chapter 2 of the Acts of 2023.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A reminder that anyone who would like to listen to or view this meeting while in progress may do so by accessing the link that was included on the meeting agenda posted on the city of Medford's website.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If despite our best efforts, we are not able to provide real-time access, we will post a recording of this meeting on the city's website as soon as possible.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A reminder that given the remote nature of this meeting, tonight all votes from the board will be made by roll call.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Please know that the project materials for all projects before the board can be viewed on the city's website

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: at medfordma.org.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You can also, you can click, from there, you can click on current seating board files.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Danielle will provide the link in the chat.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm going to do a roll call, appointments for the board.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Vice chair, Emily Hedeman.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Present.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So our first item on the agenda for today is a special permit drive-through use.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The 3850 Mystic Valley Parkway, Bank of America.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It was continued from 9-20-23.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The applicant is applying for a special permit for a bank with drive-thru ATM at 3850 Mystic Valley Parkway, which is the Wagons Plaza.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The special permit grant authority is the city council, and it has been referred to the city board for the board's recommendation on the matter.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The matter has been continued several times in order to redesign the site plan to satisfy planning staff and for sign off from other tenants of the shopping plaza.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: An overall project summary is that the existing site currently houses a surface parking lot and is bounded by commercial properties to the north, Leonard Street to the east, Locust Street to the west, and a northern access drive to Meadow Glen to the south.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The proposed project will construct an approximate 5,413 square foot bank with one drive-through lane and one drive-through bypass lane.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm going to now invite the applicant to present any updates to the proposal.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Danielle, can you please introduce all members of the applicant?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I don't think it's a motion to table it to the end of the meet or later in the meet and just to another date certain.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We're going to go to the next item on our agenda, which is 590 Boston Ave site plan review amendment.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The applicant is applying for an amendment to the previously approved site plan, special permit, and variances for the construction of a mixed use building that will contain 45 residential units and approximately 1,464 square feet of retail space with parking at grade located at the property 590 Boston Ave, Medford Mass, 02155.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The original project was approved by the Zoning Board of Appeals in July 2021, but the design has been slightly revised.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The applicant is invited to present to the board.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Danielle, can you please introduce the applicant?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you for your presentation.
