[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We know, we understand that we no longer need a parking variance and we, and there was, we, I could see the differences in the design.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But I'm trying to better understand where we stand right now in reference to compliance with the department heads comments.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And, um, I guess in the variances, if the city can pretty much point that out, I know that this was approved previously in 2020 with lots of conditions, but I'm having a hard time synthesizing all the information as you're presenting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: overview of exactly what variances that we're looking at right now and how far they are from compliance with the department heads.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Oh, no, the city at this point.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Plan development district 1 and 3 to 21 point court.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is a public hearing, and I will read accordingly.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The Medford Community Development Board shall conduct a public hearing on October 4th, 2023 at 6.30 PM via Zoom, remote video conferencing, relative to paper number 23-407, a petition by the Medford Housing Authority to amend zoning map, City of Medford maps dated April 13th, 1965, as referenced in the Medford zoning ordinance, chapter 94-2.2.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The amendment proposes to change the zoning district designation of the property one and the three to 20 Walkland Court as depicted on sheets one to six of the plans entitled ALTA slash NSPS land title survey prepared by Fuston O'Neill and dated February 6, 2022 from apartment one zoning district to plan development district, which would have new development standards per Medford zoning ordinance chapter 94-9.2.3.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Danielle, do you want me to take it from here?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Do you want me to keep going or do you want me to give an overview?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: in the Medford City Council Chamber on the second floor of Medford City Hall.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: 85 George P. Hassett Drive, Mesquite Mass, and via Zoom.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A link to the public hearing will be posted no later than November 10th, 2023.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: um, what's there now and what will be allowed there for the PDD.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The first hand that I saw, well, Danielle is going to manage the public comment queue and read any previously sent emails and letters.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But I do know that Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Roberta Cameron was the very first person to put her hand up.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I'll let Danielle take it from there.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Cal, please go ahead.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Danielle, can you unmute Cal?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I actually was going to just refer to the actual application as read last as was noted last previous meeting on where the findings were and what is being done for environmental site assessment.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And at this time, if you can also just I'm going to refrain from the parking and anything else that does not deal directly with the amendment and outside of the.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The actual zoning itself, but if you can just tell us a little bit more at this point.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Just to reiterate what has been done.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: As far as environmental, not so much mediation as of yet, but what has been done as far as environmental impacts on the site.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Assuming that it's not in the actual that no one has can grab it right now.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you so much.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm actually going to, at this time, if there's no other comments that need to be read or there's no other hands up, I'm going to close the public comment period.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And at this time I will defer back to the city and just, if the city can highlight for us in a high level vote point and give us some information, give the board and the public some information about how these goals align with the city's goals, how this project aligns with the city's goals.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: or I can actually, Danielle, did you want me to read those out or did you wanna touch base on them to give the public a better idea?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you, Danielle.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: One of the things that I wanted to flesh out without going into full detail is the 40B statute.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm not sure that the public is fully aware of what 40B and how it affects SHI, which is the state subsidized housing inventory.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There's a certain percentage that every community within the state of Massachusetts has to hit.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And if there's not a low to moderate income housing that's met within a community, then

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: that community is subjected to a 40B, which is MGL chapter 40B, which is a comprehensive permit law.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that's what Danielle was referring to, where a developer can come in and take your prime space and it doesn't have to follow regulations.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So this is a better way of controlling your housing when you have a housing production goals.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And the city can actually speak more on that, but I did want to flesh out some of the acronyms that we were using to discuss the housing goals.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Are there any other questions from the board at this time?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I agree, Vice Chair Hedeman.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: As I said, it's not that we were neglecting your comments, but they're more specific to the site itself.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And this is, we're trying to get the zoning done so that we can get the project to move forward.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If the project moves forward, once the zoning is approved, then we can do our due diligence and making sure that it conforms to all city ordinances within.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So in saying that, if there's no other,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Good evening and welcome to tonight's meeting of the community development board.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'll call the meeting to order.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Let's begin with some procedural matters.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: First, I want to read that this hearing of the Metro Community Development Board has been conducted via remote means.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings as provided for in Chapter 2 of the Acts of 2023.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A reminder that anyone who would like to listen to our

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: listen to or view this meeting while in progress may do so by accessing the link that was included on the meeting agenda posted on the City of Medford website.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If, despite our best efforts, we are not able to provide real-time access, we will post a recording of this meeting on the City's website as soon as possible.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A reminder that given the remote nature of this meeting, tonight all votes from the Board will be made by roll call.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings as provided for in chapter 2 of the acts of 2023.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: that was included on the meeting agenda posted on the CF Medford website.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If, despite our best efforts, we are not able to provide real-time access, we will post a recording of this meeting on the city's website as soon as possible.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Present.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings as provided for in Chapter 2 of the Acts of 2023.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A reminder that anyone who would like to listen to or view this meeting while in progress may do so by accessing the link that was included on the meeting agenda posted on the City of Metro's website.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If despite our best efforts, we are not able to provide real time access, we will post a recording of this meeting on the city's website as soon as possible.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I just, you know, I just did my walk on that or I just I was at the grocery store on that side and I wish I had a time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So let me see where this, I wanna see it visually, off paper kind of thing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So that's more of what I was talking about.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's not gonna be every single project, but just if the board wanted to see something that they had an interest in seeing on the ground.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That's all, not everything.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think a lot of the things that we can pretty much tackle

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: virtually, but just if there was like an extra, not to burden the board more, just giving them extra help in trying to figure it out, that's all.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You want to make sure that you're using the board's highest and best use of time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But I just know that there's just been a couple of instances that I wish I had a little bit more time to myself.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so I was just opening it up for the board.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Regular meetings of the school committee include this presentation of the public agenda item to give any resident the opportunity to place a presentation before the school committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A resident may only present once at any meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: These presentations are an opportunity for the public to make a presentation to the committee, but are not opportunities for a dialogue with the committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If one or more members of the committee wishes to have a conversation about the topic presented, a member may request that the item be added to a subsequent regular meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We voted to apply for this?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think we all certainly appreciated that we were going to get an opportunity to only promise it as I read this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There are one or two things that, you know, I read one, the district is putting out tons of communication, too dense, not too way, need to find balance and simplicity, coordinating communication, different methods, platforms can be difficult for administrators.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you, I read the document that member Ruseau provided to us in detail, and as a former representative to with shore.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I am very familiar with shore.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And in fact, remember, Hank Owen, the director.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: of many years, very rightly, is a wonderful wonderful person.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The question that came to me is that this is basically calling for a fund to be put aside for capital improvements for sure, which makes a great deal of sense, but I didn't see anything addressing

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: the potential for, if by any chance, something should happen to the shore such that it would cease to exist, what would happen of the money?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so there was no, I didn't see any line item which suggested that it would be split back between the districts or anything else like that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And while it is perhaps far-fetched to believe something will happen after the successful run of shore, it seemed to me that some

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: some notation should be made about what would happen to that account in the future if it was not used.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Well, my suggestion is that simply that should be added to this document.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And again, I'm happy to refer it to your attorney as to whether that needs to be or not.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But that was my one concern.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Otherwise, I would make a motion to support this paper.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Second.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Motion.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Should it be a roll call?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think it should be a roll call as regards to finances.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mayor?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Member van de Kloet.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I was asked to inquire about this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So the original date that employees were supposed to give you documentation was September 8th, and then it was put off to the 17th.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Could you explain why that happened?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think that perhaps the interpretation might have been by some people that it was, oh, people aren't getting their stuff in, so we're giving them extra time, and they're dragging their feet.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I wanted to make it clear that, in fact, we are having great cooperation with our labor units.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Right, well I think we're all very thankful to our labor units and I'd like to make a motion that the school committee endorse the agreements that were set forth around.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Would you say around the mandatory coven 19 testing and proof of vaccination requirements.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay, member McLaughlin is next.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mayor.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: While we're under the topic of transportation, it would seem we received a letter from a member of the public, which would be appropriate to read at this time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Please, thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So community member Eleanor Klein wrote us to the school committee account regarding bicycle racks.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And she wrote that she wants to draw our attention to the bike racks at the middle and high school.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: She included some photos of the bike racks, which she says the racks are outdated models

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and unusable and difficult to use.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: In addition, they represent a very small percentage of available space dedicated to students alternative non-fossil fuel dependent transportation options.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: She says she knows that the ones at the high school are frequently filled.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm sure the bike commission CC here can be valuable resource for ideas.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: With the partnership connector she writes the opportunities for middle schoolers to bike to school safely will be expanded.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: In addition, we as a city need to work on ways to encourage more cycling.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I would love it if we could start by making sure an ample quantity of usable racks are installed at our middle and high schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is there a plan or discussion around bike racks currently in our budget transportation planning?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If not, please make sure that this is added to the mix.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thanks very much, Ellery Klein.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I do want to note that Dr. Cushing did respond and is willing to further the conversation and work with whomever he can to make this happen.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We're allowed one delegate.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Right.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Excuse me, Mayor.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, we need to nominate our voting delegate in an alternative.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you so much.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We took a roll call.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Before we do that, after that, as we're taking things out of order, I would ask that we move on to the presentation

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: of the advisory committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mayor, I am happy to stay here to get to the entire agenda, no matter how late we go.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But in the meantime, we have an audience.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we know why they're here.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We have an advisory council.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We know why that we're here.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We've already asked them graciously, not really asked, but

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They graciously sat here for our wonderful presentation to Toni Wray.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We wanna take up our seventh graders and that I think it's only appropriate.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I guarantee you to my colleague, we will get to everything on the agenda.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No one's gonna rush out of here.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The only thing is, I wondered whether we should specify one, because if there's one or more, or because sometimes if you're putting in one, putting in a second one might not be that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I don't want to limit it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So this is our rubric, and it was used by our committee to evaluate the names of the submissions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The rubric outlined three different criteria.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: the potential for the name to bring the community together, two, the potential for the name to stand as a role model for Medford students, and three, the potential for the name to represent Medford community's proud history.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Each one of the criteria had a scoring range from one to four, four being the highest a name could receive in any category, and one being the lowest score that a name should have received.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thus, the top score of any one suggestion that they could receive is a 12, and any name with a 12 would be significant to multiple historically marginalized groups and not polarizing, known for exceptional deeds, community involvement, or contribution to society with a historical notable legacy that would last decades, or if it wasn't a person, it would still have historical significance that would last decades.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And lastly, if it was a person,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They would have lived in Medford with a Medford specific reputation, or if it was not a person, it would have a long standing ties to Medford with a positive history.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Our public participation process.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: After all of the names were scored, the top scoring 15 names were to move on with the public participation.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: However, due to a tie, we ended up with a top 17 names to move forward.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And then after looking at the list, we realized we had accidentally removed a name that should have been considered.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So we therefore added that name on to continue with the process, leaving us with 18 names to present to the public.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: On May 11th, the committee adopted and formalized a process of how we should receive public input on those 18 names as outlined in a resolution brought forward by Heinrich Ginnies.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And a subcommittee was established to create the public input form.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And the survey was open for one week to collect written responses for or against any of the 18 names.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The survey itself was translated into Spanish, Haitian Creole, Arabic, and Portuguese.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There were hard copies also made available at Medford City Hall and the superintendent's office.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And overall, the committee received over 1,200 online responses and 39 paper submissions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The top 18 names were also independently researched and rescored by each of the committee members.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: via the process previously described by the rubric, all 23 members of the advisory committee did this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The scores were then collected, averaged, and ranked as one point for the committee members to consider.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The committee then moved forward to reduce the finalists down to the

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Using an adopted process as outlined and brought forth by Patrick McCabe, the committee started with a list of names in alphabetical order, and if a committee member had stated that that name was their top three, that name would remain in consideration.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If no one on the committee said they would include that name in their top three, that name was stricken from the list.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This reduced the official list down from 18 to 13 names,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And next, every committee member was given up to three minutes to advocate for which nominee or nominees they thought should be sent forward to the school committee based on their own research, the rubric and public input.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Each committee member voted for one of the nominees.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And after the first round of votes were recorded, only three of the candidates had received a vote.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And a motion put forth by Paul Donato Jr.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: was made that we should just accept those three and send them forth.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that was adopted and the three names that received votes were on the board.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so our first few names that, these three names were Missituk, Jean Barry Sutherland, and Belinda Sutton.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The first of the three names here for you tonight is Missituk.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The land that the city of Medford sits on was inhabited by the Massachusetts tribe and other Native Americans for thousands of years.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The indigenous people that lived on the land called the river Missituk, which means Great Tidal River.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: As English colonists came to the area, the name of the river was altered in a more familiar English word, Mystic.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The river has been very important throughout the history of Medford, and it was used for fishing and for water by the indigenous tribe, and then by the colonists, and it also became essential for trade.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It became a subject of poems, such as, Over the River and Through the Wood, and Paul Revere's Ride.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This river has been a source of community pride for centuries.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The Missituk River,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: as previously mentioned, has been bringing people together.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It was a source of the food and water for indigenous tribes and the first colonists.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It then became a place that allowed Medford to take part in trade industry, being a port and preparing goods to ship out and even building ships.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The city of Medford grew because of the Mistook River.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And today, the river is used for walking, hiking, boating, fishing, and other various community events.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There is a widespread effort underway to continue to work to restore the river and the land surrounding it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And by using the Native American name, Misutuk, we are taking time to honor those who had originally inhabited these lands and taking a step to acknowledge the past and as we do this, stepping into the future.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: These are just three responses that we received from the community input survey.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There were so many wonderful responses.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And even though that this was not a vote, all of these responses were used and considered and provided the committee wonderful information into getting us to these final three names.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: These three quotes here really exemplified why Missittook is a positive influence, not only for the city and for the students of the school,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: but also for the rest of the children in the community.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Some of the feedback expressed that it was a reflection of the river and how the river has been a focal point for our community for centuries.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: People also shared that it acknowledged the native people for who originally inhabited this land.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And it also provided a physical connection between our past and our present.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It was also shared that people liked it because it wasn't a single person.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: but rather it celebrated a shared space and an aspect of a physical environment.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And lastly, Missittook represents Medford's proud history.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: As previously mentioned, the Missittook has been here long before Medford has even existed.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The Missittook watershed was home to the indigenous people of Massachusetts prior to colonization of the area by the Europeans.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The name may have morphed into Mystic, but it does not diminish the role or the value of the Missitook River and what it has played in building Medford by providing resources of not only food, but also trade.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The river powered tide mills that allowed for the process of corn, tobacco, textiles, and wood.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It was the home of the first bridge over the river, allowing the city to play a key part in the founding of this nation.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The river is also the subject of well-known poems and stories.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And while the river may now be known as Mystic, the name Mistituk gives nod to those who came before us, honoring them and acknowledging their language and homelands.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's a reminder that Medford's history didn't start when the Europeans came here.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It began long before the first boats arrived.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, so at the present the 27 letters have ballooned over 40.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I'm going to I'm going to condense them where appropriate.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: first from, and I'm starting from the ones that, the first one that came in was from Carrie Parker of 6 Hurlcross Ave.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Next letter I received was from Ellery Klein.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Please know that I am supporting you tonight as you face a contentious meeting regarding the school name change for the Columbus Elementary.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I would like to just offer one thought.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A friend of color told me she felt that naming the school after an enslaved person, Belinda Sutton, was not inspiring for the kids of color in the building.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: While I initially liked the story as Mrs. Sutton used her obviously strong powers of persuasive writing and the US justice system of the time to earn her freedom and a recompense for her

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: experience of one of the worst injustices a human being can face and hopefully went on to a better life and freedom, I was willing to hear and absorb this perspective from my friend.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: While I do think it shows agency and power on the part of Miss Sutton, and one could argue that Frederick Douglass and Harriet Tubman were also enslaved, yet nevertheless,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: inspiring fears, I do want to make sure that we have heard from enough voices of color to feel comfortable choosing Belinda Sutton as the name should we choose to do so.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If the voices in support of the beloved Medford-educated Jean Barry Sutherland are still unanimous and no hidden secrets have emerged, I also think this is a fine choice.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: However, I would urge the mayor to set firm guidelines, which we have.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I fully remain in support of the name change of the Columbus to one that is more in line with justice, freedom, hope, and kindness.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Michael Denton, One Bellevue Terrace.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: All three choices are fine, Missittook, Sutton, Sutherland.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I would, however, offer the following for your consideration.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Of the three choices, Missittook would serve as an ongoing acknowledgement of the indigenous people for whom this land was stolen.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: in the grand scheme of thing that represents a small step, but a step nonetheless toward healing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Another of the choices has been Linda Sutton would serve as an ongoing acknowledgement of the black people who were kidnapped from their homes in Africa and forcibly brought to the country and made to work as slaves.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Your third choice, Jean Barry Sutherland would honor the first principal of the school and a person who had a big impact on a number of lives.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: On the surface, it seems like a fine choice,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: However, given the larger historical, cultural, and societal context in which we are living, it would also be a choice that serves to reinforce the status quo.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I imagine some might be thinking that choosing the name after Jean Barry Sutherland would be a good compromise name because she was a great educator who impacted a lot of our lives.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But please remember this, it's never been more clear than it has over the past five years that this country needs healing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Shall I go on to a different?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay, we've got people standing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, yeah, we'll take, and then we have, and then we're gonna go to virtually.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Hello, hello.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'll continue with reading letters that came in.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: From Barry Ingbar of 9 Draper Street, he writes, I support a new name for the Columbus School that is positive, inclusive, and anti-racist.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Terry Biscardi of 28th 9th Street says, I am okay with all three options.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I am thankful for changing the name

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Columbus School.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Maura Albert of Arlington, we'll skip.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Lisa Eichel says of 19 Dearborn Street, I think it would be a wonderful to rename the Columbus School and hope you'll vote tonight to make this change.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We should have a name that all of the community is comfortable with, not just some.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Maggie Petillo of 32 Irving Street says, just wanted to thank school committee and show my support for renaming.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We want an inclusive anti-racist and progressive name.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Katie Ryan writes, Katie Ryan of 15 Canal Street says, I write to you tonight for the last time to urge you to be strong tonight and to stick to your morals and what you know is right, even in the face of hatred, even when people don't actually know you, disparage you, and accuse you of character traits and political agendas that you do not have.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I am able to write you because I was a recipient of special education services when I was a child in the 1980s and 1990s.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: When the Columbus Elementary School was first named, I would not have been able to attend it, and neither would many of my friends and loved ones.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I am glad that progress meant I would be included in schools, even though when kids with disabilities first went to public schools, people didn't like it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Today, disabled people are included because people fought for change and fought for equality.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: People change, times change, and we see positive progress.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you very much.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mimi Oliver writes, I strongly support changing the Columbus School.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Name does not name a particular person.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Katie Lagusa of 93 Gaskin says, I'm writing in support of changing the name of the Columbus School.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So Columbus Day and all of the family emphasis on Columbus Day that followed is related to my family history.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: My dad's family immigrated from Sicily and faced discrimination here in the U.S.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: My understanding is that Columbus Day was created in part as a way to uplift Italian heritage in the U.S.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and to ease tensions between the U.S.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and Italy.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Columbus was one of the many people who changed the world through colonialism and capitalism.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: All students should learn about him and the truly new interconnected world he helped to bring about as they study history.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: but I do not want my children to have to extend a school named after someone who represents the beginning of an era of mass exploitation.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: What is the holdup?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I love the idea of naming our school after a local courageous and creative person.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Lisa Foss of 78 Sagamore Ave says, while I understand that when the Columbus School was named, the name was chosen with the best intentions and I believe that should be remembered.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: However, as we become more aware of how we have neglected to meet the needs of everyone in our community, I truly believe it is time to change the name.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Diane Bellinger writes, I am writing in support of changing the name of the Columbus School to something more positive, inclusive, and anti-racist.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I stand with the children of the Columbus who chose Missitook or Belinda Sutton as the new name for their school.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Teresa Racicot of One Bellevue Terrace writes,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The three names you were voting on are all fine choices, but two of the names show conscious thought of Medford moving towards a more inclusive and anti-racist future.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: When we think of the horrendous acts of genocide, renaming the school to honor either the indigenous name, this area, or to honor a black woman enslaved at the royal house, who was the first African to ask for reparations.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Clearly one can see that either name is a good choice towards healing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I hope that you vote for one of these.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: OK, thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And thanks for all the work you've done on the budget, as well as Michelle and the rest of the team.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, the school committee received a letter this week from some of our CCSR students asking about our user fees.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And this has been something that over the years we've sought to reduce user fees.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Now, it's a fairly substantial number.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And perhaps, Mr. Murphy, do you know how much user fees bring in or approximately?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So anyway, this is certainly another concern.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I know that we have taken great pains to make sure that students who could not afford user fees were in fact waived, yet the students are bringing it before us.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I realized that at this point now we've set our budget number.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We're also clearing that there's going to be some level of,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: change yet in the budget as they normally are.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think it is something that we should take up again at a school committee meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I certainly know that for years and years and years, the ideal thought would be that we would waive all user fees.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But it's always been a budget impact, just the way the transportation is and everything else.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So if we can look at it in the future, and again, the students spoke up, I would certainly like to

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: hear more from their concerns, because I guess in many ways, I was thinking that we were meeting the needs of students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If we're not, we need to know that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you, Mayor.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'd like to make a motion that we accept the budget and put it forward to the city council.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and Maureen Lavin.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Rachel Puri discussed health education.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: She gave us a presentation.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: She mentioned that Medford is aligned to national standards.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: DESE is editing the 1999 frameworks and will put it out for public opinion.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So because of that, that's why we're right now aligning to the national standards.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We use the Michigan model based K to 12.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We spoke about this

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: at some length later in the meeting as well.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: In the elementary, social-emotional is taught by classroom teachers, which begins in kindergarten.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: In third grade, discussions about bullying education begins.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And in fifth grade, we have introduction to puberty given by the nursing department using a Proctor and Gamble curriculum.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There are pre and post tests provided to assess student learning.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: In middle school, the students have half a year of health and half a year in guidance.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Then we talked about some detail about the curriculum in each of the years.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And again, that there are pre and post assignments.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: At high school health, it's taught by health teachers.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Again, it's half a year of health, half a year of physical education.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Freshman year is introduction to health, sophomore year is healthy decision making, junior year is healthy lifestyles, and senior year is transition to adulthood.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. Rousseau asked whether gender identity was covered in grade six to eight, and Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Perry answered that it was covered briefly in grade six.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: National guidelines on sexuality and gender identity just changed and we're adapting to those.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. Rousseau followed, said that he was concerned it wasn't presented until senior year, but Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Perry assured us that it's also presented during the freshman year.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We also talked about the right language for consent.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Perry said that the students are taught appropriate touch guidelines.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. Russo said, do we ever talk about sex in a positive way?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Perry said that the age of consent is 16.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So we talk about abstinence to adhere to that guideline.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Graham questions about the Michigan model and spoke about her concern that a consumer product video is used to introduce puberty.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And there was quite a bit of discussion about this and seeing the hopos that we could see whether there is a better film or introduction that's out there.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so that's sort of on the table to explore.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: In physical education, in each of the grades, really introduction to basic skills and concepts.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: One of the things that we talked about the most is what's needed.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We need to hire a middle school health teacher.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We need an adaptive PE teacher.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We need to provide professional development for sex education.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we need to provide professional development for adaptive physical education for the entire physical education staff.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We did talk more about the adaptive PE and asked how we're meeting the needs of all of our students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Perry said that some students say sub-separate, some go into full class, and we're looking into using something called the flash curriculum.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Graham followed and asked more questions about the Michigan model, and Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Perry assured us that it's a skills-based model.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I remembered from our, when we,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: used it when we approved it, there was a great deal of discussion about it at the time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Dr. Marice Edouard-Vincent said the Michigan model is definitely one of the most respected skills-based models.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We do need to pay attention to the national standards until DESE updates theirs.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Girls are hitting puberty at younger ages, especially children of color.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Research tells us that we need to emphasize healthy eating.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Anyway, it was a good evening, and many of the things that we talked about in terms of needs, we've picked up in our budget discussions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So that's why I'm starting there.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The purpose of this meeting is to review the health education and physical education curricula in the Medford public schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This meeting of the Medford School Committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordmass.org.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately assess the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: From four to 530 there will be a curriculum subcommittee meeting, which we held through remote participation via zoom.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The purpose of this meeting is to review science and fine arts curriculum in the Medford public schools pursuant to Governor bakers March 12 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: chapter 30a paragraph 18 in the governor's march 15th 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place this meeting of the medford school committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible specific information in the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found in the city of medford

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: website www.medfordmass.org.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by assessing the meeting length contained herein.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: access the meetings in real time via technological means.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We as parents tune in each meeting to keep up and stay in touch with what is going on within our school system.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we do not need updates on news stories that are going on within our nation that do not directly affect this school system.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Example, at the last meeting, the news of a 20-year-old man in Minneapolis who was shot by police when trying to flee while being arrested was discussed when this had nothing at all to do with the Medford public schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Three, if the advanced pathways chosen that begins, if the advanced pathways chosen that begins in ninth grade, figure four.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A, how are the enhanced classes different from the regular classes?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: How much from pre-calculus needs to be pushed into these enhanced classes for students to be ready for calculus?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Could these topics be covered in the regular classes for all students?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: B, what are the pathways for late bloomers in math to get into the advanced pathway and for students who decide to switch out?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: C, could there be another option where all students take algebra, geometry, algebra two, and then senior year when students have a better idea of what they want to do after graduation, they split into an enhanced calculus or take one of the other math options?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is very focused on the advanced students, but what are we going to do to close the achievement gap, especially from the events of the last year?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: How can we close the gap without relying heavily on summer school, excessive afterschool tutoring, excessive homework, or keeping students back?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Dear school committee members, I, Teresa Fernald from 13 Whittier Road, Medford, am submitting this request and a question on behalf of almost 40 families who have joined together in support of the expansion and further development of accessible, equitable, and inclusive afterschool care in Medford, Mass.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We request that I be granted five minutes instead of three during the afterschool topic, agenda 9.4, and that the below questions be read aloud during the meeting prior to our five minutes for this agenda item.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Medford parents for better after and before school care.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We have built a network of approximately 40 families who are ready, willing, and eager to be part of identifying and executing solutions related to the afterschool crisis in Medford.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: To build the MPS school committee mission round tables to build off of, I'm sorry, held April 5 and 6, we know the current mission statement is changing and we support this change.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: However, we would like to ask the following as it relates to the mission,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: calling for MPS to be a partnership of school, family, and community.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It says, dear superintendent and school committee members, I am writing to you as a parent of two elementary school children who are currently enrolled in the full remote learning at the Roberts and who will remain in remote learning for the rest of the school year.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I am very concerned that the students who plan to remain in the remote classes not be subjected to additional changes due to the April 5th shift to full-time in-person learning for the current hybrid students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The remote teachers have spent the last six plus months working hard to create a classroom community and new daily routines in virtual learning.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: While both of my boys are struggling with the virtual aspect of virtual learning, they love being a part of the classroom community and seeing the same classmates and teacher every day.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And as a parent, I know that the classroom routines keep them feeling grounded and secure.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If any of these things are changed now with less than a third of the year remaining, if students are regrouped and put with different classmates and or a new teacher, it will cause yet another major disruption in the lives of young children who are still living through an intensely difficult and traumatizing event.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Please do not make changes to the remote learning classrooms between now and the end of the school year."

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: right now that we had 96 people asking us to supporting the name change and we received one petition from our resolution with 391 Medford residents signing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The other last time we did receive a petition from Medford United, which also had, I think it was close to 600 Medford residents signing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I did read that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If I need to go back, I can find that and read it into, all of this will be put into the record though.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A little tricky because in this particular time, we only have three communications

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: opposed to the name change.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I mean, and we know that there are far more letters.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Some of the letters have come into my private account as opposed to the school committee account.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We did receive one letter from Mr. Petrella, which I'm just going to mention because he said that he had his hand raised or was, and he didn't get to speak at our last meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I want to make sure that we're not overlooking anybody.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, and I would personally like to ask, if people are speaking, please turn on your cameras so we can see you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's just, I know you're not mandated to, but it is much easier for us.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So if you can, that's a personal request.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If you don't want to, that's your option, I guess.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Anyway, so that's the letters received up to this point, and they've been coming in pretty consistently.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: At this point, I'll just give it as report.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They'll be all put into the record.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And if anybody wishes me to do anything differently, I can.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm at the it's at the will of the committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So a couple of different things.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mayor, like you, I went down and I distilled from both member Rousseau's and my own resolution key talking points.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I asked Peter if he would put them up.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think they're similar to yours.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There may be one difference.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Because I don't really think it's a choice between mine and Paul's so much.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think that member Rousseau, because he was dedicated to doing this, sort of got out and laid out a process and giving

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: us all the opportunity to say, yep, that works for me.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No, it doesn't.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so I wrote mine down because it was pretty convoluted.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But the six key talking points really covers the most important things.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Now, I had mentioned the other day at our meeting on Monday that I do have concerns about the timeline.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And my concerns about the timeline are because not in the first part, not the, you know, application process,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We actually have, member Kretsch suggested April 30th, the meeting is on April 26th, which both member Ruseau and myself put as the date to choose the advisory committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But it's the time, how much time does the advisory committee have to work?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And part of that is asking, what are we asking them to do?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So these are the key talking points that I put forward that you're seeing on the screen right now.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: One is how is the advisory committee chosen?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And by the way, the application, I had one additional thing about availability and time, but otherwise mine and member Rousseau's, I think we're pretty close.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and not particularly complicated.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But point number two is what is the makeup of the advisory committee?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Three, once names are submitted for consideration, what is the next step in the process?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Four, what is the charge to the advisory committee?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: What are we asking them to do?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Five is how is the chair or co-chairs chosen?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And six, does the advisory committee bring one choice to the school committee for confirmation or up to three for our selection?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Those are really the key points that member Brousseau and myself look at in different ways.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So that's just, I put that out.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I know there are many hands raised now, so I'm just gonna lay that out right now.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I would like to address one thing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Many people are speaking about all the different things that the school committee faces, and that's absolutely true.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We have a lot of work ahead of us.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: However, and part of this is being brought about, well, you need more time to hear us.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We have heard strongly from the community, and I myself have gone and spoken to some members who are very anti the change.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And it's very, very difficult.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But to say you don't have enough time, well, frankly, we're a pretty dedicated bunch all across.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I don't think that once we get through

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: the process and work it out.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And there will be some things that I speak to, like removing one piece, we'll get to it later, off of a school committee onto a committee of the whole instead.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You know, so I do, and the other thing which I think is key for me to say as the longest serving school committee member is, and when this first came up, I spoke to it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Now, when this first came up, I will tell you, and I've said to other people, I wasn't happy with the process, okay?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Because at that first meeting, I felt confident in that, yes, I did feel there was a reason to change it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You must remember that there was in light of a very

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: a spring of great reckoning and understanding of what was going on in our world and the racism that exists that we all saw with our own eyes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And there is a context to this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But 20 years ago, when we built the new schools, I can absolutely tell you that there was a discussion in the committee, in the Building the Future Committee of which I was part, about the naming of the schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And at that time, we were well aware that there were people who would much prefer it not to be the Columbus School.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I've kicked myself sometimes because I let that go, partially in deference to a community member who I had great respect for and who didn't want it to change.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But it's been a recurring

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You know, maybe you haven't heard it, but I have over and over again.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I've heard it, I've had discussions down at the Columbus School with parents.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So it's not that this just popped up and there's been, it's not been part of our discussion.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It has been particularly for parents whose children attend the Columbus School.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that certainly isn't to say that everybody agrees, but it's certainly been there.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So the time has to do with the timeline that she's suggesting is part of the discussion that we'll have.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We're sort of talking two different things.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I too, after I worked out my resolution, believes that it would be great to have more time, which is to say a number of weeks more to come to the conclusion of this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I've built in and will talk to my committee about saying that I think that once we put the advisory council together and they begin their work, that they are the ones who will need to be able to say to us, hey, we need eight more weeks, or we need 12 more weeks, or we think this has to be the timeline.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But that's a discussion that as we work out the particulars of this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The other thing is the reality of it is, and we just have to say this, and it's just blunt.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: When people are saying they haven't been heard, we have heard them.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But unfortunately, we don't necessarily agree with them.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We are not agreeing to change, to not change the name.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So people keep on saying, you haven't heard us.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Well, we are hearing you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And quite honestly, I mean, I had some great discussions and I was really moved at one point by one person who told me what Columbus Day meant in his family.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I listened and I heard that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I've heard other people say we're erasing history.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We're still going to teach our kids about Columbus.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It is part of our education strands.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's not like we're just saying, and Columbus had, hey, there were some things that were good about him.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: What we're saying is, is he, is this name the one we want to represent this educational facility in our community?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You have voted for.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: the committee, six members plus the mayor, this community voted for us to do what we think is best.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is not an easy job.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It is painful, it is tough.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: One of my committee members said to me, you know, Paulette, the problem with you is you wanna make everybody happy.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that's absolutely true.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I don't wanna piss anybody off.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And no matter what I do, I'm going to make some people unhappy in this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I am being true to myself,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I've worked, spent hours and hours.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And by the way, those hours were not conflicting with the other work that I do, talking to administration, saying, hey, can we work on this?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Hey, what about that?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay, I've got lots of hours in my day.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But trying to say, how does this process work?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And is there a way that the process can help bring this community together?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I listened on Monday when Mr. McKillop suggested that we start all over.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And for a while back, I was there.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I was wondering about that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But I came, thought deeply and said, you know what?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: At this point, we have had lots of opportunity.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: People in Medford are aware of this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I walked my dog this afternoon with someone I didn't know.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I said, wow, I've got a heavy meeting tonight.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And she said, oh yeah, it's the Columbus naming issue.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: People know.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Anyway.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: On mine, I have a separate paragraph devoted to the Columbus School.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and certainly will not be as we intended when the original motion was drawn up.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So which, Paul, if I recall, originally it was April 26th, 24th, 23rd, right on yours?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is that correct?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I pushed it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Right.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So that's the Friday.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So that's the Friday of vacation week.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that's usually the day when we're then getting our packets of information.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I gave more time, less time to apply.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I have it done on Friday, April 16th.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: which does cut off time, but it's because of vacation week.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I wanted to make sure that our office staff had enough time to collect all the applications, to collect the names, and to prepare them to give them to us as appropriate.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So that was the reason why Paul and I had a different time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I just wanted to be clear on that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: April 16th.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So in essence, people have four weeks to apply.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yeah.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Again, it just had to do with the vacation week issue.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You could, I just didn't know who was gonna be, since it's vacation week, who was gonna be in the office and they need to be collated and sent out to us.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So you could, but just realize whatever office staff

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: is in the superintendent's office or whatever.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Wait, say that again.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So Mayor, Paul and I, and this is one of those key talking points that I mentioned to you earlier, we have a big difference between us on the process of what happens to the name submissions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I have them all going, if we receive 50, I have all 50 going immediately to the advisory committee once it's formed.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Paul has a process where we wheedle them down.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: What happens is we would, at our school committee meeting on April 26, which is what he designated, and Paul, if you wanna speak to this, because I'm speaking for you,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But he had it that the school committee would wheedle down the number.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So let's say we got 100, we would each pick four.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And he has a fairly involved process where they're weighted.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I found that confusing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I thought that the whole intent of the advisory committee was, in fact, to vet the names.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I did not feel that I could receive the names on a Friday, April 23, and in our Monday meeting, April 26.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: be willing or able to then only send to the committee my top four choices.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's a very significant difference on how we approach this question.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yeah, just to answer that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Or we can set ourselves up for failure by receiving, if you're a number, Paul, of 300 on Friday afternoon, and expecting me without, I don't have any time to vet them.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And on so what basis am I going from 300 to four?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's just not real.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The reason you have the advisory committee is to do the work.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I mean, part of it will be when they will go through and, you know, the first ones, they'll, you know, but that's not, if you're having us do that initial work selection without establishing what criteria we're using, it's a crapshoot.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I think that it undermines the whole process.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So can you use mine, my wording since I worked it out?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, um, so in my mind we're not erasing history we're changing a name to what might be a more appropriate name in this day and age.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Columbus will still be taught, like you said he was a famous navigator.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There's much history there.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's to be appreciated in its totality.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It is part of the Massachusetts strands of education.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think it's both fourth and then again in middle school where students discuss Columbus.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So it's not in any way a shape to

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: remove Columbus from the curriculum or not to teach it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It is a question of saying, what name do we want to put on this building that will embrace and bring our community together?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Unfortunately, Columbus is very divisive, as you can see in this discussion.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Member Ruseau had that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Anyway, would that be acceptable?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, please do.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: First, I have a paragraph about participation by the Columbus School staff and students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And it's a separate paragraph says in recognition that the staff and students of the Columbus school are dedicated to their school.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The school committee requests the principal to create a representative group of staff to solicit input from their colleagues.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Additionally, student input is highly desirable.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And if it is feasible, student participation will be encouraged in any way the principal deems to be workable in this very short period of time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The goal of both staff and student input is to come up with three to five names to submit for consideration to the advisory committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The names will be submitted by April 26th.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So we're saying

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: to the principal, there's only four weeks.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We had originally envisioned a much greater, longer period where we were gonna get student education and input.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Therefore, in recognition of that, I'm saying, oh my gosh, you know, principal, I don't know what you're going to be able to do.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I don't, I understand to me, it's not, this is one of the problems with a very tight timeline, I believe.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's not giving a great opportunity for student input.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Furthermore,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: the principal of the Columbus or her designee, as well as two staff members selected by their peers.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And then I have, or appointed by the principal.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I didn't know which way to go.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I wanted committee input and I wanted the principal's input.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: overall intent, Columbus participation, the overall intent was that we originally said we wanted some student participation, and we were recognizing that the Columbus family if you would, including staff members should have some role.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Member Ruseau will speak to this, but he identified six members as being on the advisory council.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I thought that was a lot to ask for six members.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm suggesting that the school have an internal process, however way they want to do it, to collect names that they want to submit, hopefully with some student input, but I don't know if the time allows, honestly.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and that there would be three members from the Columbus community, and that is the staff, okay, that would serve on the advisory committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And they would be elected either by their peers or appointed by the principal, depending on what we decided.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So that was my thinking.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Right, but that was less than the six people that Member Ruseau suggested.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mayor, can I just, one thing, Paul, I just don't know, and when Kathy can, Principal Kaye can advise us on this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I just don't know with teachers being at the end of the school year,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and it's such a busy time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A part of it was I was trying to lessen the obligation, even though I totally understand they may be fully invested or want to be invested.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is part, you know, this is why I've said from the outset, oh my gosh, I've got a problem with the timeline.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's really tight.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We're not being able to achieve some of our goals.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So, you know, that's my concern.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yeah.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: For me, Principal Kaye, what I really want to be is respectful to the time, the limitations of time that you have.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I wanted to make sure that there was some place where your school was represented.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I personally understand completely that there may, you know, doing a big school project just doesn't necessarily make sense.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: unfortunately, right now.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So if you thought that, you know, if it was making everybody aware that they could submit names from your school and making, you know, that maybe would be what's really possible right at this point, making forms available, letting kids know, you know, whatever, that might be just, you know, what's real.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And if the, do you think that, so originally I think it was that you and, you know, there were five members all together.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I suspect strongly there'll be some interest so that you'll be able to have staff members who will want to participate.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Please be advised on Wednesday, March 10th, from 4 to 5.30 PM, there will be a curriculum subcommittee meeting held through remote participation via Zoom.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The purpose of this meeting is to review the ELA language arts curriculum in the Medford Public Schools, pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12th, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and the governor's March 15th order imposing strict limitations of the number of people who may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford School Committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the city of Medford website www.medfordmass.org.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media websites an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The meeting can be viewed through Medford Community Media on Comcast Channel 22 and Verizon Channel 43 at 4 p.m.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Medford Public Schools is inviting you to a scheduled Zoom meeting, mps02155-org-.zoom.us.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The number is 933-2658-3171, which is the meeting ID.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: For a phone number, it's 1-301-7158-592.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Any questions or comments can be submitted during the meeting by emailing pvanderclude at medford.k12.ma.us.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Those submitting must include the following information, your first and last name, your Medford street address, and your question or comment.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: On the agenda today, we have a review of the English language arts curriculum in the Medford public schools, humanities director, Dr. Nicole Piazza.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Superintendent, do you want to say anything before we begin?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is that in next spring?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Would every school have a pilot program?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Right, and the goal would be to adopt the program K to five.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay, I mean, I certainly understand that as a parent who might have a, you know, second grader, they're counting and saying, oh, that's not gonna be made it, you know, for two years.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm walking back a little bit and say, well, there'll be something tried in your school, but that's always the very hard part as our,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: as we look at rollouts for new curriculum.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: OK.
