[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The second letter on this topic comes from Medford United and Eunice Brown.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And she's transmitted to us a packet of information

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So it says, dear May Lungo current school committee members and superintendent Edouard-Vincent, as concerned citizens of Medford, Massachusetts, we submit the documentation to support our position.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The name of the Columbus school should remain unchanged.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We strongly believe in the proposed name, believe the proposed name change is unnecessary.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This packet includes several components, this cover letter, a hard copy of the petition description that was circulated,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: online and hard copy petitions that have been signed by current and former Medford residents who oppose the name change.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Total signatures 2,100.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Medford residents signatures 650 plus.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Differential in signatures, individuals who may not currently resign in Medford, but who have grown up in the city and who continue to have family ties or business interests in Medford.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Regarding the handwritten sheets of petitions collected, in some case, the signer signed for him or herself.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: In other cases, written permission was received to sign for them.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That is why you will see signatures with the same handwriting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: One petition site that we use required that we email the URL to the results to you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That is the GO petition site, and that was the most recent petition circled and has thus far netted us 21 names, 15 of which are Medford residents.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Those results will be sent email to the official school committee email.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Information regarding Christopher Columbus is point number four.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think that must be in the packet.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Number five, information regarding the Italian-American alliance.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We believe that it is a strong sampling of the true sentiments of the Medford community.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We want our voices to be heard.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It is disturbing that such a monumental decision that changes the fabric of our city

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: was decided with a sheer lack of transparency and community input.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A decision of this magnitude should have been advertised far and wide across all media platforms and far in advance of a meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It should not have been

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: advertised only to meet the letter of the law.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is unconscionable.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We are deeply disappointed that any steps taken to move forward on this matter are considered ethnically biased, disrespectful, and thoughtless, insulting multiple generations of Italian-Americans who grew up, lived in, attended, and supported and contributed to the Columbus School as well as the city of Medford.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: For Italian Americans, this school name has and will always be a source of pride and history.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is a passionate and personal issue for many on.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: on both sides and with other urgent matters much higher on the priority list that our city is facing, we are putting forth our best efforts to stop the Medford School Committee from changing the name of the Columbus School.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: On Friday, March 5th, Educational Commissioner Riley ordered all elementary school students must return to in-person learning effective April 5th.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This should be the school committee's only priority at this time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: To quote a school committee member and their,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And there is a budget, quite possibly the most contentious budget ever, that we will be attempting to craft at the same time as replanning this year and planning next year.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It would be a gross abdication of responsibility to the children of Medford to spend time right now on the renaming of a school

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: when issues directly related to the well-being of our children are smack in front of them.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We request that our discussion regarding changing the name of the Columbus School be tabled at this time until our children have returned to school safely for the remainder of the academic year.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Budget issues are managed and there is a plan in place to return our children to the academic year 21-22.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you for your consideration, sincerely concerned citizens of Medford.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And then I have one more.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: on this subject.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This was submitted by Brenna Christensen.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Dear Mayor Lungo-Koehn and members of the Medford School Committee, my name is Brenna Christensen and I am a graduate of the class of 2020 from Medford High School and a former captain of the varsity softball team.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I write to you today to request a name change to Columbus Memorial Park

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: the Crystal Campbell Field and to incorporate the name changing of the field to the future name change committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So she's recommending that we change the name of the Columbus School to the Crystal Campbell School.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Crystal Campbell was a Medford native, a victim of the Boston Marathon bombings.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: She was an active member in our Mustang community and was in the band along with the softball team.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Crystal Campbell was known to light up any room she walked into and she loved sunflowers.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: She is an inspiration to our city, our home, our residents, and our athletes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Since 2013, the varsity softball team has held the Crystal Campbell Softball Tournament in mid-April at the Columbus Park Softball Field.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: During the two-day tournament, us Mustangs competed against Boricua, Swampscott, and Arlington Catholic High School.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We actively fundraised during the tournament and throughout our season to donate to the Crystal Campbell Scholarship Fund.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: On this day, our community comes together as one and united.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We are truly Medford strong.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Although this tournament may only be two days out of the year, during our entire season, we wear her name on our jersey.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we wear it with immense pride.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's a day when we give back to the community and honor Crystal's legacy.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Not only is the Columbus Park field home to our high school Mustang softball team, we share this field with our youth softball program and baseball as well.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We meet our forever friends, learn sportsmanship along with the importance of responsibility.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But for all of that, we make memories that will last a lifetime.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Each and every play on that field, we keep crystal close to our hearts and play in our honor.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I respectfully ask that we use our Medford strength, come together as one and rename our fields.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Let's continue the pride we feel when we wear Campbell on our jerseys and with a positive change to our city, the city we all love and with gratitude get to call home.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Kind regards, Brenda Christensen, 80 Fern Road.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So excuse me, she may be asking just for the fields to carry the name and we would do that under a separate consideration, but we might forward her email to the advisory council anyway.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, can I just, there's a curriculum subcommittee meeting from 4 to 5.30.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Correct.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So clearly people thought that we might be changing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There was also a petition submitted by Medford United

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think it is appropriate for me to just read this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It says please join Medford Mass residents in signing this petition requesting the Medford Mass School Committee and it names us immediately rescind their vote to change the name of the Columbus Elementary School in operation since 1929.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The name change was approved without community input.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Community input and transparency should be sought before major decisions are made.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Please sign the petition so we may right this wrong and be the vibrant community we are.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There were 395 Medford residents on this, but more than, and with 1,426 additional names.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: On this,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It is our custom to ask for addresses.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It was just signed with names on the emails I was receiving, you know, I don't think people are necessarily clear all the times that they're supposed to have their address as well.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I started writing back to people, but frankly, there were so many kind of got out of hand.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: All of these will be submitted to be part of the record.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'll work with Susie on that tomorrow so that we're sure that they're read into the record or they're written into the record.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think at this point, what I hear your intent is that we're gonna go ahead with the meeting we have, but I do want you to, I wanted to present both the pro and the con and the very deep feelings that people have both ways, very deep feeling.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And if I can interject a personal note,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The question is in this very difficult discussion for in our community because it is and has been divisive is how can we come together in a positive way.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that is my deepest hope is that we will find a way to find some common language and common desire around this issue.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: so that, in fact, it doesn't divide us, but it brings us together in celebration of a rich Italian culture, which maybe isn't defined by the name Columbus.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, I guess one of the things which I'm wondering is if there's a way, you know,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: we need some help, I think, bringing our community together on this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And, you know, I think it's deeply painful to see such a large rift and people on both sides, you know, obviously very committed, but I don't see yet, you know, I don't see a bridge forward.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And if anybody, you know, I'm wondering whether there's any sort of

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: any steps we can take, and if any community members have some thoughts in this of how we can help bridge this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I know that many people have suggested that we understand the Italian community's concern about losing a landmark that is important to them.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so many of us,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: you know, there's so many different names that could possibly be considered.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If we were to not only, you know, to think about it in a broader sense as an opportunity,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You know, I personally feel it's extremely important.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I know when I first came to Medford, I found myself delightfully surrounded in a neighborhood where, you know, by a wonderful warm Italian family.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: who took us in, who was so valuable to my own adjustment to Medford, and where I learned about gravy rather than sauce.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I'm just wondering, again, whether there's a, people are very strongly feeling they're negative about taking away Columbus, but I just wanna, is there any potential of going forward and thinking about, is there any place where we might move towards honoring

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: our Italian heritage in this community with a different name.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I just want to throw that out and say, you know, I'm hoping that somebody might start thinking about that in a positive way.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: By the way, and the only other thing I did want to mention is we had originally said it was important for our students at the Columbus to be involved.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so I want to make sure we don't forget that piece.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mayor?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Excuse me, if I could interrupt for a second.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I was just made aware of a mistake which I made, and it's important enough to interrupt and say that the person who wrote it to me is correct.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: What I didn't say was that I also, when we were talking about the Columbus School emails, I also had received several emails from members of the Italian

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: American community who were not in support of the Columbus name.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And the person who wrote me said that she did not want people to think that all of residents of the Italian community were of one mind.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I wanted to make that correction and to be clear.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Again, we'll give you the email so that everybody can see that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I'm so sorry and appreciate the correction.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Well, actually on this one, I do disagree because I think that we're going to have so many questions around how different things are going to be handled as we're coming out of the pandemic.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So Melanie, Medford was one of the key districts.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Paulette Vanderkloot, present.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mayor Lungo-Koehn?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Absolutely.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So we had the building the future committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I would say that it came somewhat similar in that there was a great deal of discussion amongst in the community about the shape.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And then several school committee members, including myself spearheaded, bringing it to the floor for discussion and, you know,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: moving it forward.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: One of the things which helped us was we had dynamic leadership of the committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Rick Orlando and Tricia McDonough really did such an incredibly fabulous job outlining the path.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The first discussions were, there was a series of events around the community, listening events, getting people's input.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: What were they thinking?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: What were they seeing?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: What were their reactions?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and their concerns as we move forward.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And remember, at that point, there was no, you know, in a similar way, we had not preconceived that we were going to build four new schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We didn't know.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: All of that came into being over the course of the process.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: of the committee looking at the various different resources, concerns, land parcels availability, but even would they be K to H, would they be, none of that was preconceived.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That was all part of the work of the committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that was then defined.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: One of the things that was extremely important was there were different phases of the committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So the first was kind of the outreach

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Then the second was taking the information and coming up with some decisions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And those ones then were brought to the school committee for our input, because if we weren't buying it, there was no way we were going to be able to sell it to the community.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And then a variety of different meetings happened around

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: uh Medford uh you know outreaching to different groups and whatnot explaining what was um uh

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: what project proposals there were, what ideas there were, and narrowing it down.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So it's really quite a process in the same way that I think that we're thinking here.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Were there discussions about educational?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, absolutely, and they need to be included as well.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: One of the things though that is very interesting sort of looking back is that there will be people who say, I just don't understand why.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And they really have no understanding today why certain decisions were made back then about either the placement of the schools or why there's a K to eight and a middle school on one piece of property.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So that's one of the interesting things as time goes on, those pieces are lost to the community.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And then we have people saying, I don't understand this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I can tell you that all of those decisions were thoroughly vetted

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and that there was a basis for each one of those decisions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But over time, it does get lost.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that's a valuable thing for me to realize as we go forward with this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I do wanna mention, by the way, that there was at the time, the third stage of building the future committee, which is what we called it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The third stage was the high school.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And there was some work

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: you know, things done over time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And then at some point, Dr. Perrella, you may recall, the former headmaster of the high school, he put together a, he wanted to put together a grant and he looked very much at the library area and discussed a lot about what should be happening educationally in that area.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I thought it was a very thorough vetting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There was a, at the time,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There was a, they put together a presentation.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that's something that you know as we're talking about the things we're talking about not just the physical structure but how is the building going to be used educationally, we should, even though of course I'm sure it needs to be updated but we should look back to that, what happened at that point to.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The, it was a very dedicated group of people.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They had to be able to meet.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think at first we were meeting weekly.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We could check with Rick Orlando and Tricia about exactly that, but it was a long process.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I would say that it was probably about a year before we came

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: was the first presentation and the first narrowing down steps was, you know, it was a significant process of time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I don't know if that answers the question.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Right.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We certainly had a few staff, but there were also people who acted.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They might have attended the meetings because they were giving information.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Right.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You know, so it depended, but I think we were we really started at ground zero without great

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: you know, with no preconceptions about what was going to happen.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: One of the things I just wanted to mention was the importance of also having

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: members go out and even if just in the initial process we did visitations to other school districts and that was so important and that's really harder to do right now because of COVID but you know most of us are framed you know we know our high school maybe we've been in another one but we certainly you know haven't been in a lot and we we went to quite a few other districts and that was

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: very instrumental and that required that people were also available to take some time during the day.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that was important because it excited us incredibly to see, to come out of our world and also to see what was being offered

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: in other districts.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so I just want to mention that, that maybe it can be conveyed somewhat by people visiting and then doing presentations.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They can be, you know, that might be a job, if you would, that some people go, a smaller amount go and then make a presentation.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But that's just another aspect we want to make sure we're doing is visitations.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Stone?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Russo?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Vanderclute?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Lungo-Koehn?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, so we met on November 18.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Present was myself, Jenny Graham.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mia could not make it, so Paul Rousseau attended in her place.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We began with a presentation from Tanya Sullivan and Alex Lark, co-chairs of the Medford CPAC, and they made a presentation reminding us that they speak for 20% of Medford Public Schools students and

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: that they've been advocating for a disability awareness program for many years.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Also, Melanie McLaughlin also attended, and she was the previous head of the CPAC, and also was very active in this program.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: advocating for this program.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Joan Bowen and Susanna Campbell presented the disability awareness in the classroom presentation.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Susanna Campbell is presented an overview of the course that she ran last year and is going to now run again this January.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The professional development is

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: available on the Professional Development website and is now open for registration.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's open to all staff, not just teachers.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The program is going to run Thursday afternoons from 3.15 to 5.15 in January and February via Zoom.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The course includes the history of disabilities in the U.S.,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and U.S.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: legislation, ableism, belief in our society that not being disabled is the norm, disability etiquette, so teachers can model disability etiquette, and asking a person what they want, if they want assistance rather than stepping in, and the unique needs of students with various disabilities, and also tools to break down stereotypes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Key curricular concepts are positive representation of people with disabilities in content area lessons, universal design for learning helps all have better access, anti-ableism language practice into content area lessons, reframe misconceptions, building a more inclusive environment and creating a better community.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The next steps,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: is to recruit is to have the PD course January and February of 2021 then recruit volunteers to pilot a disability awareness curriculum in February 2021 and then

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: a pilot in classrooms, March to May 2021.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is not a one and done, and this is one of the most important things that really was stressed in the meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This disability awareness, we want it to be embedded into everyday instruction, so that it's not something that which simply just happens once, it's a, you know, get some fanfare, and then it's left behind.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Rather, the concept

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and the awareness needs to be embedded into the curriculum so it is ongoing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That was a very important point.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We talked about a book that one fifth grade teacher was using and the lesson plans that had come out of that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Last time, 48 teachers took the course and it's hoping that there will be as many this time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's done on a volunteer basis.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And the end result is creating curriculum units that can be shared amongst our staff.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Again, we talked a little bit about why we weren't doing a specialized curriculum, but rather embedding it in.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: CPAC had done research on this in past years and there had been an attempt at the one school, but it ended up being a special event rather than having the long-term impact.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Let's see.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We're starting from the pilot and we're growing from there.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Susanna Campbell mentioned that we're taking a two-pronged course.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: One is about teaching students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The other part is teaching teachers to use universal design to help them become more knowledgeable about disabilities.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We've asked that there would be a report and update at the end of the year, and that's been scheduled.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so we'll be reporting back to the committee about how many teachers signed up and took the course and how many volunteers we had and how we were able to implement this this year, this year being 2021 in the spring.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Lastly, I just want to mention to you that the

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The next meeting is on December 10th, but that is this Thursday.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we're going to be looking at the math curriculum.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We also wanted to convey our thanks both to the, particularly to Tanya Sullivan and Alex Lorick of the CPAC and to Susanna Campbell and Joan Bowen for all the work they did in giving the information for us for this subcommittee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That's it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I just want to be clear on making sure that I understand the teacher's statement and the information that, Tony, you're supplying.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Up to this point, my understanding was that there was only one in-school transmission.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Do we have any more than that at this point?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But we've heard that there's a large number of teachers out at the Roberts in particular.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That's because they are quarantining?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So a positive case that was in school, is that correct?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: we are not seeing in-school transmission.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If I understand it correctly, what you're saying is that because of the testing and our ability to pick up cases, we are getting to those students and faculty members before they've actually become positive.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is that correct?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Right.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I mean, I certainly understand the, you know, when all of a sudden we hear that there's a greater number of teachers who are on quarantine.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I certainly understand.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I think all of us feel this right now, this anxiety as we see the case number get higher and higher throughout not only Massachusetts, but the country.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And, you know, sort of

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: it's very unsettling.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But what you're saying is so far the data says that we're doing okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Now, by no means am I dismissing the anxiety attached to being told you should quarantine or whatever.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I mean, I certainly understand that that is an important piece of what our staff and teachers are conveying to us is that they're nervous about it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But what you're saying right now is there's really been no change in the data, which would suggest that we need to do something different in terms of having students come to school.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is that correct?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I guess then the next question really goes to the superintendent.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: When we see the number of staff getting higher because they're on quarantine, do we have enough?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I know that there's been an incredible effort

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: to cover classes and that the administrative people and others have just really stepped up and covered.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But when we see what's going on at the Roberts right now with a certain level of teachers being out, are we able to cover the classrooms?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is it still working?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: OK.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Notify parents, caregiver of the target.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: When does that happen?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I understand timelines are tricky because there's holidays, there's weekends, there's whatever.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But yet without any timeline, you kind of take away some level of teeth to this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Now, my colleague Melanie brought up many good reports and I really do like the idea of a simple one page thing, a summary, in some ways.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But the other thing which makes me a little bit nervous is that because this is so comprehensive, I'm not really comfortable just approving it tonight.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And normally I would expect that this would go, and I know nobody wants to have another meeting, but normally I would expect it to go to rules and regulations or whatever policy.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So rather than just approving it,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If we're not gonna send it there, and I don't know the will of the committee, I would suggest we lay it on the table and we have updates, the one page update added to it before our approval at the next meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But I would like to, I'm not gonna make the motion, I'd like my colleagues to weigh in and let me know what their comfort level is.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yeah, that's kind of an unusual way for a school committee to do business.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I mean, because part of me would say that you'd certainly be following this better policy.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But I guess I'm comfortable with that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: What about the timelines issue?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: OK.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And to add the date of the incident.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: precisely you are either amending or what your resolution would be.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So could you give us the wording so we understand?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So to clarify, if there was the Brooks School classroom, second grade was sent home, it would say, you know, so sort of a red flag, current closures, Brooks School, grade two.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So if we- Select grade two or something like that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Right, so that's just a total hypothetical to be clear.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But then the question is when we do that, and this goes back to Marianne, is the whole confidentiality issue.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And are we really giving people more, I mean, if grade two is closed at whatever school, okay, wouldn't automatically, you know,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: parents would be notified, let's face it, the school would soon know, what are you really accomplishing?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You know, Brooks grade two, Roberts grade four, you know, Cohart C, you know, that would work.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Let me ask the confidentiality question first.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So, Mayor, I actually had the floor, but I wanna get to, I know Mr. Began has had his hand up for a long time and there are others, but, and then I'd like to make a statement afterwards.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I don't think he heard you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So, some of the speakers made points that I wanted to make and first I will start out with Mr. begins point that the really great news is just the one in school transmission.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that's, that's just fantastic news and.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: we can certainly hope that we can continue that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: To the speaker who talked about the role of the school committee and us representing, well, we do.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And when I was elected, I always take that a certain amount of people at least have enough faith in my judgment.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Sometimes we will disagree, but overall, you have listened to me enough and you have some level of faith in my thinking and in my judgment.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: As a school committee member, I have watched our superintendent and her team very carefully.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We looked at the policies that we've outlined and I see them following them and working very meticulously as many of the speakers made reference to.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I have personally no reason to question her judgment on making a call if we were

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: facing a situation, I believe that she would evaluate with her team and with the city people, and also maybe a call to the school committee members, because we certainly would want to be kept in the loop, but I've never felt that I've not been kept in the loop by the superintendent.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But I wouldn't need to be called into a special meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I wouldn't want to put that as this body, the school committee, now would be the ones who make that decision.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I have trust that the school committee has selected our superintendent to carry out our policies and I have every reason to believe that that's what she would be doing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I would support the motion by my colleague and also like to thank everybody for all their

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: work on these issues.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I would support the clarification that member Graham spoke to.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: In the general sense, not specific, because I think we went through the discussion about that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so I think that's good.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If you wanted to do an analogy, we could talk about snow days.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And some might say, well, Paulette, you're making it so simple.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But frankly, when there's a snow day, a superintendent makes a call with a lot of different inputs about the safety

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: of the travel for our students, travel for our teachers, the conditions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: She confers with other experts.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: She might confer with other superintendents as well.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And there's always going to be people who are going to disagree with the superintendent.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And there's always going to be people, and luckily we've heard from some of them tonight, which is nice that you've taken the time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: who's going to support the decision.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, it's a simplification, obviously this is far more difficult.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: To the speaker who said you're not giving parents enough, well the problem is that this is a pandemic and all I can say to parents is

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: At any point, we need you to think about your backup plans.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I am sure many of you, all of you, are thinking about that on a day-to-day basis.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We are in a circumstance that calls upon families to be flexible and nimble in the most difficult ways, which obviously none of us would possibly choose.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So on saying all of that, I would support leaving the decision.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I always feel that as a school committee member, ultimately, as I vote on the superintendent's contract, that is my probably most important role in so many ways besides making policy.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And this superintendent, Dr. Marisa Edward-Vincent and her team have showed extraordinarily dedication and also have worked

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: very closely with the school committee to make sure that they are doing what we are asking of them.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'd like to move the question.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Do you want to do the amendment first?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: OK.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: On the amendment, can we just lump them together?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Please.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: OK.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: On the amendments, member Graham?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Kreatz?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: McLaughlin?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Stone?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Rousseau?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: to determine whether the schools need to close or should remain open.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We're, we're saying the superintendent, the school committee is not going to be called into session to make, to make, to take the vote.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That's just an unreal place.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I mean, we have meetings every two weeks.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's not like this committee is just going to abdicate and walk off.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We have continued meetings.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We have a meeting of the curriculum subcommittee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Please be advised that on Wednesday from four to 530, there will be a curriculum subcommittee meeting held through

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: remote participation via zone.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The purpose of this meeting is to discuss a plan for incorporating disability awareness into daily instruction as a pilot program in the Metro Public Schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12th order submitting certain provisions of the open meeting law,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: 301 paragraph 18 in the governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This meeting of the Medford School Committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the city of Medford website at www.medfordmass.org.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: In the event that we are unable to do so despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or Medford

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: community media websites on an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record or of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The meeting can be viewed through Medford Community Media and it says on Comcast Channel 2 and version Channel 43.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: However, there was a change to that which I'm going to find in a second.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, so the ramp, as I understand it, was put in to assist loading and unloading, particularly of the musical instruments and whatever.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And it was never meant to be ADA accessible.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If you recall, there is an ADA accessible ramp at the front of the building.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: My safety concerns, though, is that because it is there, that it opens us up to concern automatically.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: As you think about it, there is no railing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: When I come out of the building at night from a concert, I have been concerned on many an occasion that someone could make a misstep in the lowered light, even though we've improved lighting there, but it'd be highly possible.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that's for anybody, not only somebody who might also use the ramp, which might have some concerns, maybe wheelchair, whatever, it's clearly too steep for,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: safe wheelchair.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So, but that is not the designated ADA ramp, but it exists.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And again, it was put in for, you know, all of a sudden it appeared and there was a reason for its appearance.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But for me personally, from the time it's gone in, I've been concerned about it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You're at the front of the building, and you're looking at the doors.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And the ramp is, part of it is stairs, but the ramp is right there on the left.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No, no, it's outside.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Outside.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So you've probably been up and down it 1,000 times, Melanie.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: For me, it's not so much an accessibility issue as my concern about what if someone makes a misstep off the side.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I was just going to say that it seems, you know, Mr. Rousseau is presenting certain information that Tony's unaware of.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that needs to be a private conversation between the two of them if information wants to be shared so that she can verify it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Because at this point, it's only, you know, working on hearsay, if you would.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: OK.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So, you know, I just, I'm not privy to the details of it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: None of us are, except perhaps the two of you, and somehow or another, it doesn't seem like it's really moving us ahead.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It sounds like there's some will to have further discussion on this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I have a hard time because I know I'm not an expert.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I know I'm a school committee member who has great intentions and wanna do the best for our kids, but I'm not an expert on this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so that means that I have to listen to experts.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And in some places I'm a little worried because I feel like some perhaps of my fellow school committee members think that they can interpret things in a better way than some of the experts.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I'm not,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm feeling a little uncomfortable about this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think that we do need to move on.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If we're going to have a meeting on it, where the potential would be maybe next Monday, if I threw out a date.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I don't know what the will of the entire committee is at this point about it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm definitely feeling uncertain.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I understand arguments that I'm hearing, but

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You know, what are the major question is, I've heard some things about metrics and looking into how Tufts changes us, our potential numbers.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Clearly, Mr. Rousseau is saying that the current policy that we have is not accurate and needs to be updated.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But at the same time, I heard the superintendent say something about that it was being updated

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Member Graham?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, I just wanted to say thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Clearly, some of the photos we saw enjoying themselves.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I'm sure that behind each one of these, there's many more stories that could be told.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But it's nice, especially when we have this kind of meeting, which has had its difficult points to then have this bright side.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So thank you very much for your report.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, I wanted to go back to the elementary portion and ask specifically two things.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: First, we talked a great deal about the Columbus second grade and bringing in a second teacher because of the unique circumstances that had happened, but I don't see that reflected in a split or have we brought in a second teacher?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Are they working in unison or have each taken a portion of the students?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Right, especially as the students had begun, that actually makes a lot of sense.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Has the feedback from parents and students been positive?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So far, yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The second question I had, and I just wanted to refer to it, is at the time when we discussed it two weeks ago, I had brought up the issue that you referenced that needing to change

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: some of the specialists, and I was quite concerned about that because I know for my own grandchild how important those specialists are to him, and were they changed, it would cause him great stress.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I was very concerned when I had received some emails about that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: One in particular stood out.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I haven't received any out,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: input after that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm hoping that means that the new specialists have quickly, the kids have quickly adjusted, but that was something that was unexpected and I'm not totally sure whether it was, I know it hadn't been communicated to us, so I didn't understand it was happening.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Are we stable at this point with the specialists and are you getting any other feedback about that?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I know, you know, in my own, obviously, I don't think it's the ideal situation by any, you know, stretch, but I think that what I'm hearing is really it's what you had to do in very unfortunate circumstances.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So, you know, I keep on putting that, trying to put that into perspective.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And, you know, today we had to, we were asked to submit videos for, to the McGlynn for their Medford Pride Day.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And one of the things, words I had to use was flexible and proud of our students for being flexible, because I think that's such a key here and something that we have to keep on patting them on the back for, and also to our teachers and staff too about,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Patterson is saying.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Member van de Kloot, yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mayor Lungo-Koehn.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There we go.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So the curriculum subcommittee met on Wednesday, February 26, between 4.30 and 5.30 at the superintendent's conference room in Medford High School.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: In attendance were the subcommittee members, myself and Jenny Graham.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mia was absent.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: School committee member Paul Rousseau

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: attended the meeting, as did Superintendent Maryse Edward-Vincent, Associate Superintendent Diane Caldwell, Assistant Superintendent Peter Cushing, Director of Curriculum and Instruction Bernadette Riccidelli, Director of PE Health Rachel Puri, and Middle School Parent Michelle Ciccolo.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I called the meeting together at 435 and we saluted the flag.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The purpose of the meeting was to review proposed additions to the middle school health curriculum.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We received handouts from Rachel Puri, including the table of contents for the national health standards and a table reviewing the current Medford health curriculum with the national standards.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Areas where we were not in alignment were highlighted.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Director Puri reviewed the charts with the subcommittee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Currently we use part of the Michigan model, but now we should be incorporating more areas of the most recent Michigan model edition to cover areas related to sexual health.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We are covering areas such as vaping, alcohol, drug education, nutrition, physical activity, safety, and other areas of social emotional learning.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Currently, the state standards are not out.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So at present, we need to rely on the national standards.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Director Perry explained the health is offered for a half year in grade six, seventh, and eighth.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The other half of the year, the students receive instruction from guidance in order to cover the new areas of instruction.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: In order to cover the new areas of instruction, one full-time health teacher will be needed.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Member Graham asked about the trade-off between students receiving health versus the ability to participate in band or orchestra.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Parent Ciccolo noted that her child had no health in sixth grade because of a conflict with orchestra,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: In seventh grade, her child traded phys ed in order to get health instruction.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: School committee member Rousseau noted that often students on IEPs miss subjects like health.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Assistant Superintendent Peter Cushing said that our kids are under a constant bombardment on vaping and other risky behaviors.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: He believes a trained health professional is of highest priority, a must have.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Guiding staff not trained to teach these health areas.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The superintendent concurred and noted that budget decisions are going to be tough because of the many needs.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Since the new curriculum covers areas related to sex education, such as gender identity, anatomy, puberty, and contraception, all parents will receive the opt-out notification, which the district has used for many years.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The sequencing of the curriculum will be given careful consideration.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The high school ninth grade health class will be reviewed and updated.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Scheduling at the middle school is challenging.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Member Graham offered the following statement to summarize our current position.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We recognize that there are scheduling issues that mean parents have to make choices that we would rather they did not have to make.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We are very aware of the issues and are working to address them.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Motion by Member Graham, seconded by myself.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The Curriculum Subcommittee recommends that the school committee adopt Growing Up and Staying Healthy Michigan model health curriculum with supplements in order to assure that we are aligned with the national health standards.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Roll call was Graham, yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Van der Kloot, yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Stone was absent.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Motion to adjourn at 5.30 by Member Graham and seconded by myself.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And the motion passed.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So we would like to make a motion tonight.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We would ask that the school committee adopt, recommendation is that we adopt growing up, the subcommittee recommendation is that we adopt growing up and staying healthy, the Michigan model health curriculum with supplements.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I don't know.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think there were resources that the teachers would be using.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They were not specified.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: However, we did address the needs of the fact that there was concerns about getting the curriculum to everybody.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that's one of the reasons why the recommendation is to add a full-time health

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: teacher at that level, because we need to be more comprehensive in our ability to deliver the information to students, all students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: OK.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Member Graham.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I mean, at this point, I understand it's speculative, but I think planning would help.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Great, I'd love to see homework packets put together, you know, and if possible, or even, you know, read with your child two times for 20 minutes every day or something while whatever break we're on.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And the other concern I have, just with that, that goes hand in hand, is that some of our students are reliant on two meals a day through the public schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And at least, like I'm thinking at the high school level, we've got the pantry.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: could those students be encouraged to take more?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And if the pantry needs more food, could you put a call out to the community so we can fill it up right now so that there's more food available?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I'm thinking about other things.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: How can we make sure that we're being proactive and thinking about

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: supplying some food to families that might be in a particular vulnerable place.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So anyway, I'm glad to hear the administrators are getting together tomorrow.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I'm hoping that we will do this, send home information so that we don't get to a Monday morning and all of a sudden cancel and the kids haven't received anything on Friday afternoon.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: to something my colleague said that there would be our teachers and staff and whatever would continue on their regular pay scale as per contract whether we close or not that that would not affect our personnel in terms of being paid and it I'm not sure that's what you said but that's what it sounded like okay just want to be clear

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The blessing is right now is that we have quite a number of days still left.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So because of the light snow.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But saying that, I probably, there was a year, so I won't say anything.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So did all of the students buy the cancel for any reason insurance?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: OK.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And at this point in the time window, do I understand they'll only get 50% back?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we've had no talks with the company to say whether that could be?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So within that,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: In terms of the airfare, some airlines are allowing waves or will give credit for future trips.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: What were you planning on flying?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I hope that we could look into that, because it's quite a hit for a family.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I mean, it's a disappointment for students, and I feel terrible about this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so anything that we can at least get the most money back for the families.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: thought or discussion of saying, could we do the trip during the summer instead?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you for all your work and effort.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I can feel your pain.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I really appreciate your thoughtful answer and the fact that you had to make this tough decision.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Oh, yeah.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I believe I can concur with Melanie on many of the points that she makes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's not reasonable.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It never was a reasonable timeline.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It seems ludicrous that they're asking for such a quick return across the way.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: My mom used to say, it never hurts to ask.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I think putting together a well-crafted letter saying we would respectfully ask you for more time, we don't believe that this is an adequate amount of time for us to engage our families and whatever.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I mean, I would absolutely submit it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I would actually go further and talk to the other

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: superintendents who are also grappling with this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Maybe there's a few who've managed to figure it out, but I bet there's a whole lot of superintendents trying to slam this together, as we will be doing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But on the other hand, I'm not willing to leave money on the table.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so I think we need to go ahead and send it to the engagement committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think we need to write the letter because nothing ventured, nothing gained, okay?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That we should do that and hope for the best.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And in the meantime, do whatever work we can do so that we are prepared to file what we have, whether it's perfect or not, because I'm not going to leave $138,000 on the table.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I can think of many, many different things that we've talked in the budget.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: that might be helpful to our students and to all students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So, yeah.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Point of clarification, member Ruseau.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So if we don't submit the plan we automatically still get the money?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Member McLaughlin.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay, so I'm going to make this the short version because of the long hour.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But you've heard ECRI being referred to any number of times this evening.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Associate Superintendent Diane Caldwell welcomed everybody and she explained that there would be, on March 3rd, a half day of professional development session conducted by Hill for literacy and professional development would continue next year.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: ECRI materials consist of downloadable PDFs for classroom instruction and full district implementation is expected to occur at the beginning of next fall.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We received two handouts.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Dr. Chiesa spoke about ECRI as a multi-tiered program, Tier 1 and Tier 2, featuring a series of teaching routines designed to increase the efficiency and effectiveness of reading instruction in K-2.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The program is being introduced to improve student achievement in word reading and comprehension, fluency, and phonological awareness.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Tier one of the program is whole group instruction.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Tier two is targeted intervention.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Our teacher, Kristen Howell, title one at the Columbus, worked with ECRIB this past summer through a grant in conjunction with DESE and spoke highly of the program.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Also at our meeting, Michelle Donahue, a Medford resident and a teacher in another district,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: spoke to her very positive experience with ECRI.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Her district uses a different reading program than Medford's journeys, but they have the same concerns about foundational weaknesses that we are seeing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Donaghy brought her teaching materials and explained facets of the day-to-day implementation.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: She sees it as something that easily fit into her current teaching and bolstered her students' understanding.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Member Graham asked when the Journeys Program would be evaluated.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A discussion about the complexity of implementing all the new curriculum pieces followed, and we covered that some in our budget meeting tonight.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Dr. Keyes explained that it was essential not to overwhelm teachers while other new curriculums were being adopted.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Member van der Kloot asked Director Teixeira whether ECRI program would be useful for EL, and he explained he responded in the affirmative.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Parent Sharon Hayes expressed some concerns with Journey's approach to the teaching of combination letter sounds.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Diane Caldwell noted that the cost of ECRI is $275 per level.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The combined cost came to $3,300, and the cost would be covered by Title I funds.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The motion was accepted, was made to accept ECRI, was made by myself and seconded by Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Stone, and the motion passed three to one.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The chair asked about upcoming topics, and we have a list, elementary, ELA, and math, suggestion to create the overall map of the curriculum.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We reviewed, we suggested we talk about civic standards in fourth and eighth grade, the amount of assessments, possibly reviewing elementary Italian program, and win assessments.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we adjourned at 6.59 p.m.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I would like to add to this and announce that we have another curriculum subcommittee meeting this Wednesday at 4.30, between 4.30 and 5.30.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The purpose is to discuss proposed changes to the middle school health curriculum.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So we'll be meeting this week again, okay?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It will be up at Medford High School.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Medford High School.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Just one thing in the timeline that doesn't make sense to me.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I note that the sibling opt-in, opt-out form is due on March 4th.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But the open houses, the three of them occur after that deadline.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So for me, it would make more sense for the sibling opt-in, opt-out form to be sent home, to be due on March 11th.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But, you know, with... If it would work such that the sibling opt-in, opt-out form

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: is not a drop-dead, but which is to say that instead they'd be collected with the ideal on March 4th.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But if there were forms that were not turned in, there would be follow-up with the parent.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I would be comfortable with that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But that's a procedural thing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If it's meant that if the parent doesn't return the form by that date,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: then I'm not particular, you know, one way or the other, then I'm not particularly comfortable with it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But I assume you'd be following up with it?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If you can make that, that makes them more comfortable with it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I support the resolution.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We see the little free libraries

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They often thank the music teachers because it is the music teachers who have continuity from the elementary to the middle to the high school.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And what we've now managed to build with the CCSR is that there's a continuity.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: of ideals going from the elementary to the middle to the high school and soon because of this while the time the kids get to the high school of course we'll always be welcoming more new high school students but we'll also be building the space that will come up

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that's an incredibly powerful thing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Van der Kloot.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I want to know what staff are paid.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so it may be a position that even though we may be competitive with other after school programs, the fact of the matter is that if maybe we have to be better than competitive, maybe we have to be the best.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is he going to get it?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: She said, Mom, every parent is guaranteed.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It should be every parent.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I was really proud.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: two classrooms if they have to cover more because someone's out sick or someone has left.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You know, you pay different money.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: First, Superintendent, I really appreciate your fair and equitable approach to this dilemma that we've had.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: However, I do believe that it certainly is going to still cause some consternation.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: One specific question, just to start.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: In the past, the McGlynn Elementary students really had a, if they wanted to stay at the McGlynn, they did.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Now it appears that this group of students, half of them would be going to the Andrew School.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is that correct?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Now, one of the questions we've had in the past had to do with the sibling preference, and I just want to be very clear as we roll this out that the sibling preference of people, and there was a past policy and discussion that happened, and it was around the fact that

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Parents argued that they had been guaranteed sibling preference for the year after their students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So a child perhaps was going up to the high school and going into 9th grade, but another child was coming in at the 6th grade level.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And the reason behind it was that they had spent all that time contributing and building the school, and the parents had relationships which they wanted to continue.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: because of their support of the school.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I just want to be clear that as we roll this out, that's one of the things that has arisen in the past that we need to be clear on.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I absolutely understand where you're going, but I just wanted to be clear.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Right, right.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And in fact, there was a letter and the parents were able to substantiate it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: you know, policy can change.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We just need to be very clear about it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The other thing I guess is I'm curious about how you're going to roll this out now after our, I would assume we'll vote on it, but after our approval, how will you sell this to the community?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think, I mean, I believe that too.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think that the other concern that will arise will be the friendship groups.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: My child's over here at this school and all the friends are going over to the other school.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And to that means, I think that it's really, really important

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: that we do a very concerted effort of understanding, especially now that it's very clear that we're going to have these new mixed groups of students, that we foster activities and create opportunities for kids to get to know new children, and we make that very much part of our goal as we enter this new phase.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So earlier tonight, we in subcommittee talked about sort of the guiding principles of the Medford School Committee.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And what really we said was that we were here for all students and to make sure

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: that their educational opportunities were the best for them.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And if I go back to that guiding principle and I look at what the superintendent just presented to us, I see that there may be some short-term pain.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The long-term gain of making an equitable middle school environment is where we need to go for the benefit of all students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I appreciate that my colleague

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. Ruggiero might like some more time to digest it and to talk a little bit about rollout.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So just a quick update, as you know, the MASC hosted the annual joint school committee superintendent conference from November 7th to 10th in Hyannis, Massachusetts, representing Medford were myself, member Paul Rousseau, and our associate superintendent Diane Caldwell.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Throughout the conference, we attended numerous presentations and events, including the update from the Department of Education

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: a presentation involving all stakeholders, school law and legal updates, a presentation on the new super induction program, and many others.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I myself was particularly pleased to have the opportunity to hear the new Commissioner of Education, Jeff Riley, speak.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: He felt like a breath of fresh air and it sounded to me like he would be more concerned with the whole child

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and will take a more measured approach to standardized testing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It was the first opportunity that I had to hear the Commissioner, and I'm hoping that we might set up to invite him to Medford to see some of our wonderful programs, completely like I thought about the CCSR or some of our early child programs.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'd like to get the Commissioner here, and it was really wonderful to hear him

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: He truly was a breath of fresh air.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Another highlight of the conference was the Thursday morning keynote speaker, Mark Brackett, PhD, a founding director of the Yale Center for Emotional Intelligence and professor in the Child Study Center at Yale University.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Dr. Brackett explained his RULER approach, an acronym for the five key emotion skills of recognizing, understanding, labeling, expressing, and regulating emotions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I referred to him at our last meeting when we were talking about social-emotional learning issues

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: He is going to have some work that we might want to participate in.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: He was very, very inspirational, and so truly a highlight of the conference.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Lastly, I myself facilitated the Division II meeting, which is our geographic region for MASC.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We re-elected Stacey Rizzo from Revere to lead the division.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: She's a wonderful, active school committee member in Revere.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And finally, I think that the MASC conference is always a way to connect with fellow school committee members from across the Commonwealth and gain an understanding that what we are dealing with here in Medford and issues that are important to us are also important to our fellow school committee members.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It provides an opportunity to get a much broader view than just simply, you know, in our local community.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is a very exciting opportunity for the band.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The pep rally was just great.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The performances were just terrific.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Vandekloot.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is what we developed consistent with, does it make sense to have that happen before we see what the state has in there?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Van der Kloot.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I just think that that was Judy Lonergan's baby and that she was the one who started it and I think that whenever we talk about we should mention because it was a great idea and she really put a lot of work into it and she got it off the ground and we're really, our schools have really benefited from the fundraising that the run accomplishes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I wondered, as you spoke about the zones of regulation, I know that the Medford Educational Foundation had received requests from different guidance Councilors or whatever for signage, for

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: materials.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Have we been able to provide our students with, or each of our schools with some materials to support the zones of regulation?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yeah, I think that the thing was, our concern was that, well, at the time, it seemed very piecemeal, and we wanted it to be

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: unified so that every school had the same sort of things.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: To be honest with you, I see that as a school initiative since we're doing this, that these are things that we should provide our classrooms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I'd really like to have an opportunity to sit down and see what we've got and what in each school and what really the Councilors and teachers, the principals feel is necessary in terms of some visual reminders.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Right.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The foundation didn't want to fund piecemeal projects.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's not what we're about, so we've really been waiting for this year to see what the initiative is going to be.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And perhaps we'll be able to support it to some degree, but only if we have an understanding that we have a comprehensive approach to it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Also, I just want to mention that

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: When that entranceway was refurbished some years ago, the idea always was that there should be plantings on that hill adjacent to the steps.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And it's always made me very sad that that, you know, it's just kind of a dull space rather than an exciting space.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm very enthusiastic about this project, and I really appreciate the idea.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I have only one concern, which, you know, maybe you've thought about.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I could see that a fallen apple could make a great missile, ball, substitute ball.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So, projectile is probably the word that I really want.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I just want to

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: ask if you've considered that, and how would you make sure that students are respectful of the fallen fruit, and that we wouldn't find it being used for target practice against the side of the school?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: maybe some signage too about this project and what it is might help so that the students really are respectful of it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Does it matter that there's a slope?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay, and how about watering the trees?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Making sure they've got enough water.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I'd like to also thank my colleague for donating the blueberries and being a help in this project.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think it's great, girls.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you so much for your presentation tonight.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Vandekloot.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Just two things.
