[Paulette Van der Kloot]: that we are, in fact, not funding a program that would not be appropriate.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And when I spoke up before, I do believe that the Educational Foundation would, in fact, benefit from something.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Because we are a 501c3, and I think everybody who is a 501c this, you are required to have bylaws.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Now, how formally you play them out is another thing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But somewhere in your organization, at some point, you have had bylaws, because if you're a 501c3,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You needed to have that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You needed to specify how the offices worked.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So even though, Paul, I understand what you're saying and your concerns, some of that actually is called for by the nonprofit status.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Anyway, otherwise than that, I think that we can send it off.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But those were some of my initial concerns.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Before you move on, though, I do know that there are members of the

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Are there any PTGs out there that would like to speak on this topic?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Van der Kloot.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It would be a shame if this conversation ended with any thought that we're not appreciative of the extraordinarily hard work of our PTOs, PTGs, booster clubs, and any other organization that gives up their time and effort to

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: raise money for our students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I know from experience, I know from my time on the school committee and before that, how hard people work and how often it is a very small group of people in the end who really bust their butt night after night making sure that all of the

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: money is raised that the kids get the opportunities.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so I just think that it's really important.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You know, many of you won't remember this and the only two maybe in the room right now might be the superintendent and

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Diane Caldwell, remember that before I was on the school committee, one of the things that I did was an event called It's Your Night to Shine.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that was a thank you to all the volunteers, all the PTO members who busted their butts, because way back then, as someone who was just beginning in all of this, it was so clear to me that there were a few people who just kept things going.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And they were all, blessedly,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: that it's always somehow worked out that we have a group of parents at each and every school who will take this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And sometimes it's because the void, they see that no one else is there and they step in and they make it happen.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So within all of this and this discussion, by putting in something like this, ultimately the desire is not to just oversee and enforce and say you have to do one more thing, but to be helpful, to be positive, and always to say thank you so much for the work that you do.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Van der Kloot.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. Ruggiero, as a new colleague, I want you to know that I have no doubt at all that you meant no harm.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You meant to be speaking up for parents, and in fact, were responding to parents' requests.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I know that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I know that you did it thinking that you were doing the very best thing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I have no, absolutely no doubt about that at all.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I don't think you meant to be heavy-handed.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I don't think you meant to cause this uproar.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I don't think so at all.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I do think you were inexperienced, and frankly, you learn.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Because you see, you know that it's caused great upset.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That was very evident the other night.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We agree that we've now got some new things that have come out of this, maybe, and maybe that's all for the better.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But there were some really hurt feelings.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The treasurer has asked for an apology.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Saying I'm sorry doesn't cost you anything, and it would help to move on.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I understand that you didn't mean to hurt, but frankly, you did.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It happened.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's happened to me.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I didn't mean to, but it did.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I said, I'm sorry.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Sometimes those two little words are just the easiest thing to say if they're heartfelt and meant, because I truly believe, I truly believe that you meant no harm.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I look forward to working with you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I look forward to

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: figuring out what it means to be a team.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You and I have already had some discussions about personal styles, whatever.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And in my view, it is time to move on.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But in order for that to happen, you need to say something.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Before we leave tonight, I wanted to bring up one other discussion, which I thought Mr. Ruggiero might.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Today, Mr. Ruggiero put online our packet of information, and I think that there was

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: One piece, which I was uncomfortable with, which actually had to do with the ski trip, it didn't have names on it, but if there was names, I wanted that to be posted.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I wasn't certain that I wanted everybody in the public to know exactly where the kids were going, what time they were going, whatever, just as a safety thing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think that

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: it's long been a thought that I know other school committee members share, that some of our documents, rather than having this big stack of papers, could be online for us as well.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so I think that we should take both things together, figure out, there were some questions about

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: afterwards, which people in the public raised, which I certainly wouldn't have thought about.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So it was interesting input of saying, how do you best post our information for our meetings?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I'd like to make a motion, maybe in conjunction with Mr. Ruggiero, that we search how we're going to effectively put our documents online, both for the public and also so that we can

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: minimize the amount of paper that we have for our meetings.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: As a long-term school committee member, I can tell you that I could devote, I mean, whole rooms, buckets fills of these exist, and frankly, it's just way too much.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: OK, I made a motion.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Do we want to just officialize it?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Sure.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We'll include that in the amendment.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: All please rise and salute our flag.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Vander Kloof?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So just a clarification.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: On the front page, you say we'll cap the charges at three meals.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: for middle and high school students and five for elementary.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But then if I understand it, they can still take a regular meal.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm just trying to figure out, first of all, in terms of the alternate lunch, are cheese sandwiches an option for all the time for everybody?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay, because one of the things that we worked hard is not to signal students out.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So three days in a row is pretty short time, is what I'm concerned about.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I'm just thinking about for a family who's got a sort of short-term crisis, I mean... In regard to

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Well, you know, obviously my concern is for the student who might have not yet signed up for

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: reduced price lunch or something, but all of a sudden there's a crisis.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I just wouldn't want them to be in any way signaled out.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is consistent, you say, with other school districts?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we have to have- We have to have a charge policy, yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Well, I'll be curious, yeah, what other people think about it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Sure.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I think that having some threshold where the account is followed up on, that's not a problem for me.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I definitely think that all of a sudden the kid goes through the line and they get a different meal is a problem for me.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I would rather them still be able to take their regular meal.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You know what?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I mean, because it still shows up, and there's still, the follow-up would still be necessary, right?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, they would be in a negative capacity going through the line.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I mean, it says here, I mean, because there's a punishment instated in here.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The child will be allowed to take a meal.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that meal will be continued to be charged to the account at the standard lunch rate based on their meal benefit.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So if the meal is three and a quarter, even though they're getting a cheese sandwich rather than chicken nuggets, they're being charged the same three and a quarter.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: To me, there is a punishment there, and I'm not comfortable with that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I understand that it's important for us to have some thresholds so that parents are contacted.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I understand that the alternative lunch is

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: meets the same criteria, but I'm not comfortable with that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I'm comfortable with saying, OK, flag the account.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We need to talk to the parents.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That's fine.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That makes sense.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But I'm not comfortable with changing the lunch for the student.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That just doesn't sit well with me.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, I just want to thank Dr. Perella for being proactive on this issue.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think it's extremely important.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I mean, I remember when vaping was considered to be healthier than cigarette smoking.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so the idea was that you were stepping down if you were vaping.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And clearly when you presented the last time and mentioned jeweling and the amount of nicotine, I was shocked.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And clearly this has taken on a new concern for us.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So thank you very much.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You're welcome.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you very much.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I've been thinking about this for the last couple of weeks and really wondering what to say to my esteemed colleagues who are leaving us.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: First, I'm going to turn to Robert Emmett Scurry, who's been sitting next to me for an awfully long time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We've shared many different instances, but amongst our colleagues from the back, and some of these names won't mean anything to some of you, but some of them will mean a great deal to others.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So we sat with Bill Brady, Lena DiGiantomaso, the esteemed Fred Pompeo, Mary Alabirdy, Carol Sharpton, Fred Lasky, Jack the Bulldog Buckley,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ed Nolan, Ron Vining, Beth Fuller, Sharon Guzik, Bill O'Keefe, the Honorable Mike McGlynn, and now our current colleagues, Erin, Mia, Kathy, Anne Marie, and of course, Mayor Burke.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I don't know if I got everybody, but I think I did.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And through that, we've had a lot of different experiences.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: With Lena, we were climbing on roofs of buildings to check out the roofs.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And then we had many, many long evenings as we prepared for building new schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I suspect, Bob, like me, your proudest moments come when you go see your name on those plaques in the new schools, because those were incredible, an incredible period of time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Bob, you and I haven't always gotten along.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We're not always on the same page, but I know and have never doubted that your heart is in the right place.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And this position here and your commitment to Medford and to the students of Medford has meant everything to you and that you have given a great deal of time and energy to the city of Medford and the children of Medford and our families.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So colleague.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Almost four decades.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Colleague, I'm not quite sure what it's going to be like sitting here without you, and I'm going to miss you, but I know that you will take your time and commitment and energy working on behalf of students in Medford will continue.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So thank you very much for your service.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Now, Mrs. Cugno, you've not been here quite as long as Mr. Scurry, but your impact has been huge over the last, is it 12?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: 12 years.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And in that time, we also got to see your family grow up.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that was pretty cool.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So because those boys, they were in elementary school way back when, and now they're in college or beyond.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And it's really been quite an amazing ride, Anne Marie, hasn't it?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Don't do this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So in that ride, one has to say, I mean, through all of the different things, of course, like with Mr. Scurry, the building of the new schools was just an amazing project.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so many meetings, so many, so many meetings that we spent.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: talking about the bigger picture and then the small picture.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And the small picture was the color of the paint, the location of the switches, and then the bigger issues of equity, which was so, so, so important to us.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And you were part of that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You were a very big part of that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And it fueled your becoming a school committee member.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we were all grateful for that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You went on, though, to be very active on the state level, first by becoming the head of the division two for the MASC, Massachusetts Association of School Committee, and then working your way up to an incredible year as being president of the MASC and representing Medford.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I quite honestly believe that, sorry,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Most of my colleagues here don't really realize what you did during the course of that period of time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But I was fortunate to sit on the board with Anne-Marie and be able to experience her leadership and the amount of work and travel that it took over that time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So Anne-Marie, maybe, luckily, my voice is giving out.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: An option for all the time for everybody?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: OK, because one of the things that we worked hard is not to signal students out.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So three days in a row is pretty short time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: is what I'm concerned about.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Well, you know, obviously my concern is for the student who might have not yet signed up for a reduced price lunch or something, but all of a sudden there's a crisis.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I just wouldn't want them to be in any way signaled out.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is consistent, you say, with other school districts?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we have to have?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We have to have a charge policy, yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Well, I'll be curious what other people think about it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Sure.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I think that having some threshold where the account is followed up on, that's not a problem for me.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I definitely think that all of a sudden the kid goes through the line and they get a different meal is a problem for me.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I would rather them still be able to take the regular meal.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I mean, because it still shows up.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The follow-up would still be necessary, right?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I mean, it says here, I mean, because there's a punishment instated in here.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The child will be allowed to take a meal, and that meal will continue to be charged to the account at the standard lunch rate based on their meal benefit.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So if the meal is three and a quarter, even though they're getting a cheese sandwich rather than chicken nuggets, they're being charged the same three and a quarter.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: To me, there is a punishment there, and I'm not comfortable with that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I understand that it's important for us to have some thresholds so that parents are contacted.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I understand that the alternative lunch meets the same criteria.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But I'm not comfortable with that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Substitution.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Don't substitute.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I'm comfortable with saying, OK, flag the account.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We need to talk to the parents.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That's fine.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That makes sense.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Hold tight.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And present at the meeting were Mayor Burke, Vice Chair Anne Marie Cugno, Arenda Benedetto, Kathy Kreatz, Mia Mustone, Robert Scurry, and myself.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Also attending was Michael Ruggiero and Paul Rousseau, school committee members left.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Also present were the following Deputy Superintendent Beverly Nelson, Assistant Superintendent Diane Caldwell, Director of Pupil Services Kathleen Medaglio, Director of Curriculum Bernadette Scurry.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: uh, Director of Finance and Administration, Kirsteen Patterson, Director of Foreign Language, Rita DeCarlo, Supervisor of Health Services, Tony Vento, Assistant Athletic Director, Rachel Perry, um, Headmaster, John Perrella, Principal, Paul DeLeva, Principal, Jacob Edwards, Assistant Principal, Nick Tucci, Athletic Trainer, Tanya Cashman, Tim Zitt, Registrar, Curtis Tootin, and other community members, including Tammy Simenotis,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: uh, Marie Petrides, Angela Moore, David Lu, Melanie McLaughlin, Tanya Sullivan, and Jameel Webb Davis.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Transcript recorder Miranda Wilson was also in attendance.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Um, the mayor, uh, the, the meeting was called, uh, to discuss school brains, the field trip policy, follow up on student concussions, and report on the North Medford bus.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It was a very substantial meeting, went on for hours.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Um, I just added that Superintendent Johnson made the following remarks the evenings.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Um, and by the way, sorry, it was there was a there was mistake.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It should be Bernadette Riccadeli.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Uh, so we addressed the four different issues.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Um, and the first item was the report of the North Medford bus capacity and ridership, uh, director of administration and finance Christine Patterson gave the

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: report and it's attached.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And Principal Tucci verified the report.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There are two buses coming from North Medford in the morning and in the afternoon there are between 45 to 50 riders daily which is within its capacity.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: At this time there's no need to add another bus.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: administration will keep the committee informed as demand increases.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The next item was student concussions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Um, we talked about this at length.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Um, as part of our discussions, parent Tammy Simonotis spoke of her son's experience at Beverly High School.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: She asserted that her son was injured during a JV soccer game and that there was inadequate trainer medical coverage by the Beverly staff.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: She believes that the Beverly schools did not have a certified trainer at the game.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Her son suffered a head injury, chipped teeth and nosebleeds.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The concern focused upon safety at away games.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Members of our staff spoke with the athletic director at Beverly, but really haven't received any more news.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mrs. Simone was pleased with how Medford handles injuries, but was very upset at the Beverly response.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Concern was particularly high because the game was allowed to go on after the injury took place.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The superintendent promised that he will be conferring with the MIA regarding this matter.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The next item under discussion was the field trip policy and administrators Paul Deliva, Tony Vento and Kathy Medaglio contributed comments during the discussions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: CPAC chairperson Melanie McLaughlin raised equity issues about the policy and commented that CPAC should have been consulted as the policy was formulated.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There was a discussion about the annual trip to New York by the Andrew School and the questions about deadlines.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Among the 90 students who attended, there were 19 students who either had an IEP or 504 plan, and this was 19% of the participants.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If we had added another bus, it would have cost approximately $7,500 and would not have made the trip doable.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: McLaughlin asserted that the trip excluded students with disabilities and that every trip should be planned to serve all interested students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The issue raised several points.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Can field trips be planned with application deadlines if those deadlines are applicable to all students?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Should field trips be limited if the economics cannot be balanced?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And should the cost of medical services be shared by all participants or subsidized by the school system?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: After continued discussion, the policy was tabled.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Administrators will bring forward a revised policy that addresses the issues.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The final issue of the evening was school brains.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Athletic Trainer, Tanya Cashman.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Tim Zitt.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Registrar, Curtis Tudin, and other community members, including Tammy Simonotis, Marie Petrides, Angela Moore, David Lu, Melanie McLaughlin, Tanya Sullivan, and Jameel Webb Davis.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Transcript recorder Miranda Wilson was also in attendance.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The meeting was called to discuss school brains, the field trip policy, follow up on student concussions, and report on the North Medford bus.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It was a very substantial meeting, went on for hours.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I just added that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Superintendent Dawson made the following remarks.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The evenings, and by the way, sorry, there was a mistake.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It should be Bernadette Riccadeli.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So we addressed the four different issues.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And the first item was the report of the North Medford bus capacity and ridership.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Director of Administration and Finance, Christine Patterson, gave this report and it's attached.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And principal,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Tucci verified the report.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There are two buses coming from North Medford in the morning, and in the afternoon, there are between 45 to 50 riders daily, which is within its capacity.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: At this time, there's no need to add another bus.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Administration will keep the committee informed as demand increases.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The next item was student concussions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We talked about this at length.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: As part of our discussions, parent Tammy Simonotis spoke of her son's experience at Beverly High School.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: She asserted that her son was injured during a JV soccer game and that there was inadequate trainer medical coverage by the Beverly staff.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: She believes that the Beverly schools did not have a certified trainer at the game.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Her son suffered a head injury, chipped teeth, and nosebleeds.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The concern focused upon safety at away games.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Members of our staff spoke with the athletic director at Beverly, but really haven't received any more news.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mrs. Simone was pleased with how Medford handles injuries, but was very upset at the Beverly response.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Concern was particularly high because the game was allowed to go on after the injury took place.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The superintendent promised that he will be conferring with the MIAA regarding this matter.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The next item under discussion was the field trip policy, and Administrators Paul DeLiva, Tony Vento, and Kathy Medaglio contributed comments during the discussions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: CPAC Chairperson Melanie McLaughlin raised equity issues about the policy and commented that CPAC should have been consulted as the policy was formulated.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There was a discussion about the annual trip to New York by the Andrew School and the questions about deadlines.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And among the 90 students who attended, there were 19 students who either had an IEP or 504 plan, and this was 19% of the participants.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If we had added another bus, it would have cost approximately 7,500 and would not have made the trip doable.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: McLaughlin asserted that the trip excluded students with disabilities and that every trip should be planned to serve all interested students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The issue raised several points.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Can field trips be planned with application deadlines if those deadlines are applicable to all students?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Should field trips be limited if the economics cannot be balanced?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And should the cost of medical services be shared by all participants or subsidized by the school system?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: After continued discussion, the policy was tabled.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Administrators will bring forward a revised policy that addresses the issues.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The final issue of the evening was school brains.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Headmaster Perella and Data Information Specialist Registrar Curtis Tudin gave us a report.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The headmaster reported that changes had been made to address the GPA concerns raised during the spring by Mr. David Lu.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. Tudin provided a chart that showed the increase in usage by parents and teachers.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: More will be done going forward.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is a work in progress, but it is moving forward.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. Liu was still skeptical about the accuracy of the reporting system.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: He revisited his concerns from last spring.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Administrators asserted that the changes would work.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The school committee asked to be informed as the year progressed.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The meeting was adjourned at 10.05.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Respectfully submitted, Paulette Vanderkoot, Secretary.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Vandekloot.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay so and at Medford high school say for the Portuguese students level one and level two would be those students who were certainly level one would be the students who were just coming to us and level two they might have been with us for?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Well, I was just curious, I think one of the concerns had to do with siblings and the ability of siblings to oversee their, you know, sisters and brothers.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay, so at some point I'd like to ask for a report on how that's worked out.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: uh... i'm happy to take any any questions uh... thank you bernadette so of the uh... corrections and changes that you've made i've noted that all the ones that i particularly had brought up the taking care of that of course now being said is my eyes lit on another uh...

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: which I think we need to amend.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So if you give me a second so I can find it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It has to do with the notification for approval or disapproval of the field trip.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And it is on page four, section three B. It reads right now, all school sponsored trips which involve overnight travel must receive prior approval of the superintendent and a vote by the Medford School Committee six months prior to the trip.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I have to say, I know that that's totally unrealistic.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think that when we're thinking about it, we're thinking about all-schools concert trips, which involve overnight out-of-country travel.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So that would be when the kids are going off to Spain or Italy or whatever, that that time frame of six months is what we would be expecting or looking for.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But we all know that there have been other overnight trips, even including, you know, the SkillsUSA program is an overnight trip.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We've had kids go to the Ethics Bowl was an overnight trip.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Those things, there was no time to give six months.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's not realistic to have our policy say six months.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I think we need a sentence which say,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: For other field trips, you know, for other overnight trips, the school committee will be brought to the school committee for their approval.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Using as timely, you know, I mean, it depends on the timeframe.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yeah, prior to the trip.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But I mean, it has to be reasonable.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We really don't like the last minute ones that, I mean, there's a last minute one because there's an opportunity that's last minute.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And there's a last minute one because nobody got around to telling us.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Well, there is a clause which allows the superintendent to approve a trip if we don't have a meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But again, I think the first sentence needs to say overnight out of country.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Travel.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And then the second sentence need to say other, I'm just trying to think.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Um, the mayor, uh, the, the meeting was called, uh, to discuss school brains, the field trip policy, follow up on student concussions, and report on the North Medford bus.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It was a very substantial meeting, went on for hours.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I just added that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Superintendent Dawson made the following remarks.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The evenings, and by the way, sorry, there was a mistake.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It should be Bernadette Riccadeli.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So we addressed the four different issues.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And the first item was the report of the North Medford bus capacity and ridership.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Director of administration and finance, Christine Patterson, gave this report, and it's attached.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: uh, Tucci verified the report.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There are two buses coming from North Medford in the morning, um, and in the afternoon there are between 45 to 50 riders daily with each, which is within its capacity.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: At this time there's no need to add another bus.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Administration will

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Keep the committee informed as demand increases.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The next item was student concussions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We talked about this at length.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: As part of our discussions, parent Tammy Simonotis spoke of her son's experience at Beverly High School.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: She asserted that her son was injured during a JV soccer game and that there was inadequate trainer medical coverage by the Beverly staff.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: She believes that the Beverly Schools did not have a certified trainer at the game.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Her son suffered a head injury, chipped teeth, and nosebleeds.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Her concern focused upon safety at away games.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Members of our staff spoke with the athletic director at Beverly, but really haven't received any more news.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mrs. Simone was pleased with how Medford handles injuries, but was very upset at the Beverly response.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Concern was particularly high because the game was allowed to go on after the injury took place.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The superintendent promised that he will be conferring with the MIAA regarding this matter.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The next item under discussion was the field trip policy and administrators Paul DeLiva, Tony Vento, and Kathy Medaglio contributed comments during the discussions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: CPAC chairperson Melanie McLaughlin raised equity issues about the policy and commented that CPAC should have been consulted as the policy was formulated.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There was a discussion about the annual trip to New York by the Andrew School and the questions about deadlines.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Among the 90 students who attended, there were 19 students who either had an IEP or 504 plan, and this was 19% of the participants.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If we had added another bus, it would have cost approximately $7,500 and would not have made the trip doable.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: McLaughlin asserted that the trip excluded students with disabilities and that every trip should be planned to serve all interested students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The issue raised several points.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Can field trips be planned with application deadlines if those deadlines are applicable to all students?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Should field trips be limited if the economics cannot be balanced?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And should the cost of medical services be shared by all participants or subsidized by the school system?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: After continued discussion, the policy was tabled.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Administrators will bring forward a revised policy that addresses the issues.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The final issue of the evening was school brains.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Headmaster Perrella and Data Information Specialist Registrar Curtis Tudin gave us a report.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The headmaster reported that changes had been made to address the GPA concerns raised during the spring by Mr. David Lu.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. Tudin provided a chart that showed the increase in usage by parents and teachers.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: More will be done going forward.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is a work in progress, but it is moving forward.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. Liu was still skeptical about the accuracy of the reporting system.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: He revisited his concerns from last spring.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Administrators asserted that the changes would work.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The school committee asked to be informed as the year progressed.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The meeting was adjourned at 10.05.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Respectfully submitted, Paulette Van der Kloot, secretary.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Here it said six months.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I would like to lay the paper on the table.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I just want to say that I personally was very disheartened when I heard that the teachers reaction was that he felt that demonized and less so I would felt very very sad because that was certainly I don't think Our intention school committee members or or maybe even the superintendent.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'd the the reality was that we have

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: gotten a lot of calls from parents whose kids were not being able to be placed in the school of their choice where their friends were.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And this is a real dilemma for us because it has snowballed.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I still am receiving emails from one parent who tells me how upset their child is because she has been separated from her friend back.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And for me, this has become this sort of like, how do we solve this issue when all of a sudden one group of parents is selecting a school and that those who weren't able because we

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We want to keep class sizes reasonable and it's not appropriate to have one school with, we can't go over contractually the class size limits nor would we want to.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So this issue of friends and how do we, how do we,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: tackle this issue so that we don't have an imbalance.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I have been to the McGlynn School.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think you guys are great.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I've had wonderful experiences, wonderful opportunities to be at the McGlynn School.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I certainly would be comfortable to send any child of mine to the McGlynn School.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And because I have history, as many of us do here, we know

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: that there has been some times where the balance goes one way and then the balance goes the other way and if I blink my eyes another year it's going to go back the other way.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: From a school committee perspective I need to parents to feel

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: good about the choices and this issue of friends, of what happens when my friends go there and it snowballs is real key for me in trying to figure that out.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That's why we've been talking about saying we want to add after school activities where kids from both schools can attend so that a club will have friends and the kid won't feel so bad about being at the other school.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I know from some people, their kids have acclimated in a positive way.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Once the parent went, once the kid went, it's fine.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But the angst that we saw and heard this summer was huge.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Anyway, thank you so much for coming down, and thank you for the work that you do for our kids every day.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'd say clearly you guys did a great job.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I just would like to respond to you, Mr. McKillop.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think we need to keep something in perspective.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Up to this point, up to this year, in the recent years, if you look at our numbers, there's been a very sort of equal distribution between the schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We've gone to many different events.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We celebrate the McGlynn, and we celebrate the Andrews.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: of that number, that certain parents that are saying, and I think Justin did a fine job alluding to saying, hey, is that being so, parents are saying, oh, well, I want to go to this school instead.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Those students are great students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I know them, and I love them, and they're fantastic students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I don't really need you to be here tonight to lecture us about what we're not doing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We've had a fine working relationship with our wonderful teachers across the district.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Because all of a sudden, we have these students who are very upset because their friends are going elsewhere.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Not one.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm hoping that we are tracking those students and making sure that we know that a guidance Councilor, the principal knows who those students are and are tracking how they're doing, helping make sure that they're getting connected to other kids in the school.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And this was clearly a great concern to the committee members.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So perhaps you could address that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We knew that- No, not in terms of that, Beverly.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: What's being done now to make sure those students are- Oh, okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Well, like I see that it says, you know, we have plans to have more clubs at the McGlynn or clubs where kids could both join.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And the thing is, I think we need to do that right away.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I want to see options so that those kids who feel that they're taken away from their friends have an opportunity to perhaps join something and not waiting until the second semester.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think we usually plan for stipends to take place.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I am So it's an interesting thing but there's always been over the course of all the years that they've been open that there are families who asked to go to one school or another and

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But not to this level.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So when we did it, it was very unpopular.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And there were many, many parents who were extremely concerned.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: One of the things which now is I hear so many positive things.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: about the Columbus that I think that parents, I've not heard anywhere near the level of concern because once people go and meet Mrs. K, they're so happy and the school is such a positive place to be.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I just haven't heard

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: that level, the ugliest word of being a school committee member is probably redistricting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I mean, really positive.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And Mia, you nearly took my breath away when you said, why don't we just do a lottery and have them do that?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Well, that might be something we're gonna talk about, but we're gonna make a lot of people unhappy no matter what we do when we talk about this type of things of equity between choice in schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's a very difficult thing as a school committee member, because we are naturally people who want to please.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And unfortunately, when you make that type of decision, you're gonna not make everybody, it's impossible to make everybody happy.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So what we have to concentrate on is we have to look at the total population of kids and say, what is the most equitable thing for our student body?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And how are we making sure?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And one of the things is when you go into those school buildings, you will see

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: that they all have the same, they have a gym, they have a library, they have a, because we were so concerned at the time of building them, that wherever a student in Medford went, that they would have an equitable building and environment to learn in, and also populate as close as we can with the same kind of draws.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is, when I've been on the committee, the McGlynn at one point was more popular, and then it became the Andrews, and then it became the McGlynn.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We've never had such an inequity as we did this year, and hopefully we won't again.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I mean, this is a really difficult issue for us because I think that we have great sympathy and we certainly want to get the kids to school.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Frankly, wherever they're going to school, we want those kids to be enrolled in school and resume their normal education path.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: As a one school committee member, I feel great sympathy, but I don't think this is in my purview as much as I might want it to be.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: May I follow up?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Right.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I don't really... My feeling, too, is that I understand you're saying we may not have the standing, but if we don't at least try.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so, I would at least want to petition them, even if it's for a temporary placement.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So, could we ask you to do that?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Van der Kloot.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I appreciate your work.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Dr. Perillo, I have to say the only thing which is just, well, I have two different things that's just gnawing at me, and I'll vote to go along with this, but the other day I overheard a conversation between two parents, and one of them said, my son has already called or texted me six times, and it was only 10.30 in the morning.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And she said, I wish they wouldn't allow this, because it was clearly, where is that separation between child and parent?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I see that as a growing,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: concern, we talk about helicopter parents, we talk about, you know, kids, they're just, the advent of this ease in 24-7 technology has also meant for some kids not being as, gaining their independence.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so I

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And at my workplace where I supervise high school students, I know that there's been a real issue where it's been very difficult to say, nope, you can't use those cell phones when you're, oh yeah, pushing a patient or taking them, you know, and having to make strict lines, especially because there's other than employees walking through the halls on their cell phones.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And, you know, when you're in the kind of environment where I work, we need to impress upon

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: our students what's appropriate and they're just so used to having ready access that when that cell phone buzzes, they're thinking they can be there.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yep, that shouldn't be the whole focus of your day.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So motion to approve?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Second.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Dr. Perla, while you're here, I'm just going to take this opportunity to mention that the school committee has been without a student representative for a long time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Over the course of years, occasionally we've had some students that we've done better or worse, but now for the last

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: last two years or more, we haven't had anybody, and certainly nobody consistent.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think it's valuable when we get to a question like this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is when, while you've done an excellent job defending your position and explaining to us the rationale, which I certainly appreciate, but this is so much a question when we should have our student representatives present.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I'm wondering if we could ask you to

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: explain to the students what the role is, explain that this is an opportunity for them.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We've had some great, you know, vocal people in the past.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We like hearing from the kids, and I'm wondering if you could help arrange that so that we could expect to have students on a regular basis attend our meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm sure there are a lot of people who will force him.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We'll be up to help you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If you do need us to come forward, and as Mr. Skerry said, to come recruit kids.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You're always welcome.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But there's always been a role.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There always is a role.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We've been to many other schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We now have them, and I feel like we're really missing out right now.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Van de Koot.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I had a couple of first nuts and bolts questions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You listed in your report Curtis liabilities and one of them was notification of rights and suggested that this could be easily resolved by adding a message to the school brains login screen.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Has that been done?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's very easy to... Then it would just seem that we should try and take these liabilities off.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Another one was the current ad hoc method of assigning user security roles.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: is unsustainable and may expose sensitive information.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I would think that that would be another one that we would need to spend some time on.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The data storage, I understand, being an issue.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So those are kind of nuts and bolts issues.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Since you've identified them, I'd like to try and resolve them.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The bigger issue that is also brought up in this report is the whole GPA system and the weighting of courses.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I think that's a much larger conversation than certainly any of us have the wherewithal tonight.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think that should probably happen within the course of meetings and probably in the curriculum subcommittee, perhaps, if my colleagues thought so as well.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think that there's a lot of input we need to get and a lot of information for all of those questions which were presented to us, really saying is that the best possible way to go in the future to determine student achievement and how we emphasize that, how we tell schools, colleges, when kids are applying,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: what sort of student this is.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It also goes on and says, you know, how do we give out awards and is it based on GPA or is it based on other stuff?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So a lot of information in that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And something that I would suggest that we send to the curriculum subcommittee, which is my subcommittee, and ponder and work on that over some period of time this year.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I just have a question that I'd like to throw out.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Since we're talking about next week's meeting, I have to tell you as one committee member, this has not been an ideal setup for me tonight.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's very difficult to feel like I'm having a conversation with my fellow school committee members.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The lights are in our eyes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We only sort of see the audience.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I'm not sure whether the television was capturing the speakers who came before us.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I'd like some thought put into this next week.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you, Mr. Superintendent, for your report.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You touched on possible federal impacts, and of course that picture is not clear to us at this time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: However, today the National School Boards Association did send out an alert because of the concern about the legislation to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act and the impact on Medicaid funding

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: for public school students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If passed at this point, it would limit Medicaid funding and it says the impact, the ability of students with disabilities and students in poverty to receive critical necessary health services in public schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The legislation will require schools to compete for limited Medicaid funding and result in the institution of arbitrary caps and how much Medicaid reimbursements are made to public schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Again, this would be another area where I know that money comes back to the city, but it's another place where we would find a loss.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They urge us to call our

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: House of Representative people.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Of course, we understand where they already sit in our state.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: However, I did want to bring it to your attention.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There is none.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is such a wonderful thing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's like a dream come true for our Medford students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But I haven't, we're really sort of talking about individual projects again and not the capital improvement plan.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Where are we on that?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And would a project like, I mean, again, we've, we've sort of had ongoing concerns ultimately about the play surfaces and the playgrounds.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I know that much work was done and there were patches and whatever, but you know, it's still out there as a project, which we, we need to take a look at.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Van der Kloot.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you, Mr. Superintendent, for your report.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You touched on possible federal impacts, and of course that picture is not clear to us at this time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: However, today the National School Boards Association did send out an alert because of the concern about the legislation to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act and the impact on Medicaid funding for public school students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If passed at this point, it would

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: limit Medicaid funding and it says the impact the ability of students with disabilities and students in poverty to receive critical necessary health services in public schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The legislation will require schools to compete for limited Medicaid funding and result in the institution of arbitrary caps and how much Medicaid reimbursements are made to public schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Again this would be another area where I know that money comes back to the city but it's another place where we would

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: find a loss.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It impacts the pie.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They urge us to call our House of Representatives people.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Of course, we understand where they already sit in our state.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: However, I did want to bring it to your attention.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mrs. Grignano.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Present.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Present.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mrs. Kreatz.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Here.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: All right.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Great.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Just about two months, within the last two to three months, a young stonem teenager lost her life.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So this is really fantastic, and thank you so much.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Motion for approval.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mrs. Cunha?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: the conference room.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Professor Carter, Ann Marie O'Neill, or individuals at SFS, me and the staff.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: President Superintendent Roy Belson, Deputy Superintendent Beverly Nelson, Assistant Superintendent Diane Caldwell, Vocational Principal Director Heidi Riccio, Director of Finance and Administration Christine Patterson, and Director of Buildings and Grounds John McLaughlin, parents Sarah O'Grady, Melissa McGinnis, Carolyn Montello, and Michelle Ciccolo, all rose to salute the flag.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Vice Chair Cunha stated the purpose of the meeting was to continue our discussions on capital planning,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: projects for the Medford Public Schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Vice Chair Cugno called upon the superintendent to begin the discussion.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The superintendent reiterated the importance of understanding the difference between capital planning projects and general repair and maintenance issues.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Capital planning is usually a multi-year group of projects.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Such projects generally require a mix of bonding, grants, and revenues.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The superintendent listed the capital projects that have been completed since FY 2000, which are attached.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Secretary Van der Kloot pointed out that the pool and the boiler project should be added to the list.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The superintendent stressed the importance of getting started.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Capital projects often take multiple years to get approval from the funding agencies.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Additionally, there are many non-school projects that need to be addressed.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There must be a balance between city and school priorities as we go forward.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mayor Burke joined the meeting and assumed the chair.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The mayor was attending a city council meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Each committee member was provided with a packet of materials.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The superintendent identified capital plan proposed on August 5th, 2016 for the committee's reference.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This discussion then reviewed the statement of interest, which was approved by the school committee at their last regular meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is only the first step toward acquiring MSBA funding assistance.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Dr. Heidi Riccio then detailed three grant awards that are moving forward to enable major improvements in program development.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They are attached.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The three grants are the Massachusetts Life Sciences Grant for $98,516, which will support the development of our robotics and engineering programs.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Number two was the capital skills grant for $500,000 to support the development of our culinary and hospitality program.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We will match this funding with both in-kind assistance from our partners in industry and labor.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Also, we will use funding that is in the reserve contingency from the science labs project.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This will require council approval.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Third is regional services grant for $200,000 to expand our shops to accommodate enrollment increases.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The focus of this grant will be

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: on our electrical program and related areas.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It will facilitate the inclusion with students from Everett who will pay a tuition.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Currently, we have 25 Everett students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We expect to increase the number of tuition students to 100 over time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We are also recapturing tuitions from Minuteman.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The grants will be supplemented by in-kind work by the laborers and Wynn, as well as the other industry partners.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The development of our shop spaces will also enable us to serve adult learners and to maximize the use of our facility.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The laborers will also help increase handicap accessibility.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The discussion moved to the high school roof, see infrared roof survey.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The high school roof needs some small repairs.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: that could be accomplished for about $25,000 to $30,000 this summer.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We would expect to consider roof replacement beginning with 2020.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This would be done in sections.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The outside schools are still in good shape.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They have another 10 years before possible replacement.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. McLaughlin was present to ask your questions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. McLaughlin then discussed the emergency repairs to the heating system pipes in A building.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: which is attached, a financial account was provided.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Member Mia Mastone asked how we could find funding for this type of repair.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Also why we are not finding money for building appearance projects.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The superintendent explained that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: he would have had to shut down a building if the repairs were not made.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It is not uncommon to divert funding for emergency repairs.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: He also reiterated his plan to add additional funds to the operational budget next year for general repairs.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Member Erinda Benedetto asked that the hanging wires in the conference room be removed from sight.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. Scurry urged more cosmetic work be done, and members Cugno and Van der Kloot recognized the need to do more with appearance, but supported the priority of emergency repairs.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Van der Kloot asked for a report on the bleachers at our K-8 schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The superintendent referenced the report from Mr. McLaughlin regarding the need to repair air conditioning compressors.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: While the schools are functional, there could be better efficiency.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There's also an attached listing there.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Curb replacement and parking lot resurfing was discussed with emphasis on the high school McGlynn and Andrews.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A report is attached.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Playground replacement at the elementary schools was discussed.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Pricing is now being sought.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There is some possible mitigation linkage from a developer to assist with the Roberts playground.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The committee received the draft executive summary for our school technology.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: As we move forward, technology is central to our educational and operational programs.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Testing, state, federal funding, reporting, and instruction are more and more dependent on a robust and reliable technology, sorry, infrastructure and tools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We are eligible for substantial funding from the e-rate program under Tier 2.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This will require a 40% match.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Technology capital investment must be an essential part of our capital plan.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Almost made it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: On the motion of Mr. Skerry, seconded by Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mrs. Vanderklift.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mayor Burke.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Beverly, I thought that the last year that we've been setting in more like seven snow days, not five.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I was surprised to see that this was, in my eyes, rolled back to five.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I would have thought that we would have called the end of school the 22nd, for instance, so to set expectations that it could go that late.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I'd like the superintendent.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yes, I guess I'm looking at it a different way.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If I'm a parent thinking about making plans,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If you say the end of the school is the 22nd, well, then I'm going to be thinking I'm going to make my plans starting the 23rd.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If you say it's the 20th, then I'm going to start making them the 21st.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'd like some other feedback, but I'm thinking that it's better to set people's expectations that there could be the possibility, because if we go back

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: to two years ago in 2015 when we had so many snowstorms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think it's an expectation thing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: What do others think?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yeah.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If we just did some further clarification.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay, fine.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So we used to go back in Medford after Labor Day.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And in fact, many families preferred it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Um, and certainly the teachers did.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The fact of the matter was with them, we were running into a problem because we were going too late

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: too far into June because we were getting more snow days.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We went through a period of years where we're getting a lot of snow days.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so with the cooperation of the teachers union, we then moved it back.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is it preferable?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Well, not necessarily.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It depends on who you talk to.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But it's because of, I mean, if we could predict snow days, we wouldn't be doing this, but we can't.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And if teachers were unhappy, they were really, really, really unhappy if, you know, school went to June 30th or, you know, when it went that late.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So that's why.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That's great.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Also, if I can follow up, I was wondering if you're seeing students who are concerned about their family's immigration status, if that's causing any angst?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Van der Klooten.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm not quite sure what you said in that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So a freshman can't take art and band together?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So is that for the whole school year, they would just have one elective?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So if they wanted to take

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So if one of the electives was guitar, they would take guitar for the whole school year.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Correct.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And the pro of this is?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I mean, the advantage?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: All right.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: OK.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The opposite of that is I got into an elective and I don't really like that one, but I love the other one I'm taking.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So there's pros and cons.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Um, will they get graded in that CTE exploration?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yeah, I just wanted to make sure that we have enough people in the schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I know you're saying you're working on it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I was thinking about a meeting I attended recently down at one of the middle schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And at that point, there was no school nurse present.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There was, in fact, maybe the only person present might have been a principal.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. Superintendent didn't say anything about forcing people to do it who didn't want to do it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm thinking that there are people who, in fact, would like to learn how to do it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Motion for approval.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The meeting was called to order by Vice Chairperson Anne Marie Pugno at 7.06 p.m.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: President Superintendent Roy Bellson, Deputy Superintendent Beverly Nelson, Assistant Superintendent Diane Caldwell, Vocational Principal Director Heidi Riccio, Director of Finance and Administration Christine Patterson, and Director of Buildings and Grounds John McLaughlin, parents Sarah O'Grady, Melissa McGinnis, Carolyn Montello, and Michelle Ciccolo, all rose to salute the flag.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Vice Chair Cunha stated the purpose of the meeting was to continue our discussions on capital planning,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: projects for the Medford public schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Vice Chair Cuno called upon the superintendent to begin the discussion.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The superintendent reiterated the importance of understanding the difference between capital planning projects and general repair and maintenance issues.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Capital planning is usually a multi-year group of projects.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Such projects generally require a mix of bonding, grants, and revenues.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The superintendent listed the capital projects that have been completed since FY 2000, which are attached.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Secretary Van der Kloot pointed out that the pool and the boiler project should be added to the list.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The superintendent stressed the importance of getting started.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Capital projects often take multiple years to get approval from the funding agencies.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Additionally, there are many non-school projects that need to be addressed.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There must be a balance between city and school priorities as we go forward.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mayor Burke joined the meeting and assumed the chair.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The mayor was attending a city council meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Oops.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Each committee member was provided with a packet of materials.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The superintendent identified capital plan proposed on August 5th, 2016 for the committee's reference.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This discussion then reviewed the statement of interest, which was approved by the school committee at their last regular meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is only the first step toward acquiring MSBA funding assistance.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Dr. Heidi Riccio then detailed three grant awards that are moving forward to enable major improvements in program development.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They are attached.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The three grants are the Massachusetts Life Sciences Grant for $98,516, which will support the development of our robotics and engineering programs.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Number two is the capital skills grant for $500,000 to support the development of our culinary and hospitality program.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We will match this funding with both in-kind assistance from our partners in industry and labor.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Also, we will use funding that is in the reserve contingency from the science labs project.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This will require council approval.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Third is regional services grant for $200,000 to expand our shops to accommodate enrollment increases.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The focus of this grant will be

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: on our electrical program and related areas.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It will facilitate the inclusion with students from Everett who will pay a tuition.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Currently we have 25 Everett students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We expect to increase the number of tuition students to 100 over time.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We are also recapturing tuitions from Minuteman.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The grants will be supplemented by in-kind work by the laborers and Wynn as well as the other industry partners.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The development of our shop spaces will also enable us to serve adult learners and to maximize the use of our facility.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The laborers will also help increase handicap accessibility.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The discussion moved to the high school roof.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: See infrared roof survey.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The high school roof needs some small repairs.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: that could be accomplished for about $25,000 to $30,000 this summer.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We would expect to consider roof replacement beginning with 2020.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This would be done in sections.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The outside schools are still in good shape.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They have another 10 years before possible replacement.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. McLaughlin was present to ask their questions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. McLaughlin then discussed the emergency repairs to the heating system pipes in A building, which is attached.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A financial account was provided.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Member me I'm stony asked how we could fund find funding for this type of repair also why we are not finding money for building appearance projects the superintendent explained that

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: He would have had to shut down a building if the repairs were not made.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It is not uncommon to divert funding for emergency repairs.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: He also reiterated his plan to add additional funds to the operational budget next year for general repairs.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Member Erinda Benedetto asked that the hanging wires in the conference room be removed from sight.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. Scurry urged more cosmetic work be done, and members Cugno and Van der Kloot recognized the need to do more with appearance, but supported the priority of emergency repairs.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Van der Kloot asked for a report on the bleachers at our K-8 schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The superintendent referenced the report from Mr. McLaughlin regarding the need to repair air conditioning compressors.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: While the schools are functional, there could be better efficiency.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There's also an attached listing there.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Curb replacement and parking lot resurfing was discussed with emphasis on the high school McGlynn and Andrews, a report is attached.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Playground replacement at the elementary schools was discussed.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Pricing is now being sought.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There is some possible mitigation linkage from a developer to assist with the Roberts playground.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The committee received the draft executive summary for our school technology.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: As we move forward, technology is central to our educational and operational programs.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Testing, state, federal funding, reporting, and instruction are more and more dependent on a robust and reliable technology, sorry, infrastructure and tools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We are eligible

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: for substantial funding from the e-rate program under tier two.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This will require a 40% match.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Technology capital investment must be an essential part of our capital plan.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Almost made it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: On the motion of Mr. Skerry, seconded by Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: tricky in our community where not everyone necessarily will have access to a computer, but many will have access to phones now.
