[Paulette Van der Kloot]: May I vote?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Van der Kloot.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Hi.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I had, for instance, some questions about the reporting of MCAS scores and other tests.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I mean, for one of the things, actually for the vocational school kids in the past couple

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They've done so well.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's been nice to have them separate just to say, look how our students are succeeding.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I was sort of curious about some of those things.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I also wanted to make sure that as we discuss this, that everybody understands that this is not a weakening of the vocational school in any way, shape, or at all, but in fact, all along,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We've been working to strengthen the vocational school and our high school as well And the collaboration between them is what what we see does this but it's not necessarily Apparent, you know when you hear it it could certainly Be taken the wrong way So I think that's why it's very very important that we go and we have some more discussion on this so that we can very quickly

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: clarify this to our community about what our future intentions might be.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Very good.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Do you envision any sort of science nights where parents are being brought in and helped, how they can help their kids with science education the way we do for math and literacy?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I guess I'm just a little bit concerned.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I was speaking with a group of parents and they told me that their child had never had a hands-on science activity.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And so, and I felt such an urgency.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Um, so that's part of what I'm trying to grasp here, uh, of trying to say is, is okay, how are we going to meet those needs sooner?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So, you've said a lot of things and I need to tell you that as a school committee member.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: First of all, because I know many of the people who are involved in this company and have known them over years.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: because of their professional positions in Medford and as Medford residents.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And in fact, if you would, divorce myself from the people involved.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The statute says that we should be telling parents that there is a option for sanitation, period.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Sterilization.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Sorry.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Sterilization.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Period.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That's okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That's what the statute says.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And what I understand us to be voting on tonight is simply, are we going to accept it?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And then incumbent on us is to let parents know whose children are renting instruments, um, uh, that they should be, um, that, that there is this option and it is an option.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That's what I'm voting on.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If I have some blinders on, it's purposeful because I don't want to get involved with personalities or, or whatever.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think it's, for me, it's a clear cut.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There's a statute.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It says that this would be, that's what the legislature has told us.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I don't have any hidden agenda.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The one concern that I do have is I think that it's incumbent on

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: us that we want to make sure that the flyer which is going out to the parents is acceptable to us.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think it probably should have a website for the parents attached to it for more information.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I don't want to scare every parent thinking that their kid now is going to die if they don't do this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think that we want to let them know that it is an option for them and consistent with the statute.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I just want to make sure.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I haven't seen a flyer yet that would go out to the parent, but rather than that flyer going directly to the music company or through whatever,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I want to make sure that we have administrative oversight of that flyer.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I was going to suggest we move the question.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Vander Kloof.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Does it make any sense to suspend the rules to pick up the adoption of Medford Conversations Project?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And that's why we're going to go ahead and say this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I have to tell you, and neither of these incidents happened inside or with anybody involved in Medford.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: discrimination and, uh, inappropriate hate.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Well, you know, let him recover.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Say a student didn't fail the course but they got a D and now they're a senior and they're realizing that that D is really going to hurt them or that they really need the content of that course.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is there a way to use it as a review or possibly to improve their grade?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And the other question I have, the only thing that makes me uncomfortable in the protocol you've put forth is the absolute.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: My preference actually would be no outside of district programs will be accepted.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: for credit recovery unless approved by the assistant superintendent or something.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Van der Kloot.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: this issue of sexting and what the long-term and short-term ramifications are.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And it isn't

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: high school students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It is the, you know, starting at middle school.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And then said, and the teacher put it on a blackboard.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And right away the kids started going, the teacher, you made a mistake, you made a mistake.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And even though all the other ones were right,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The only one that they talked about was the wrong one.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And when you do something wrong, I mean, it was such an easy how that can follow you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That's the thing that people see.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I thought it was such a concrete example that should be presented to kids about saying, you know, this is the problem.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If you make that mistake and all of a sudden you write something out or you send a picture to somebody.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: it's going to follow you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So, you know, I don't think it's just, I think the policy that you presented to us, which we will need to follow up, is a piece of the puzzle, but it's not the entire puzzle.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think that what Mia is talking about, if I may, Mia, if I think, is sort of saying is how are we making sure that within the scope of our conversations as we seek to educate our kids about social and emotional issues, that sexting becomes part of the topic.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I think it's a very important conversation to have.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: One of the things that I found on the internet just this past week is whatever is, you know, someone had 1 times 9 equals 7, 2 times 9 equals 18, 3 times 9 equals 27, and it went on.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And then said, and the teacher put it on a blackboard.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And right away the kids started going, the teacher, you made a mistake, you made a mistake.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And even though all the other ones were right,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The only one that they talked about was the wrong one.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And when you do something wrong, I mean, it was such an easy, how that can follow you, that's the thing that people see.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I thought it was such a concrete example that should be presented to kids about saying, you know, this is the problem.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If you make that mistake and all of a sudden you write something out or you send a picture to somebody, it's going to follow you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: You know, I don't think it's just, I think the policy that you presented to us, which we will need to follow up, is a piece of the puzzle, but it's not the entire puzzle.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think that what Mia is talking about, if I may, Mia, if I think, is sort of saying is how are we making sure that within the scope of our conversations as we seek to educate our kids about social and emotional issues, that sexting becomes part of the topic.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think we just need to be clear.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I did not hear that this is happening in the Medford Public Schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We are hearing that there is a concern about it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I have one question.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Van der Kloot.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Roedd e'n hollbwysig iawn.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Roedd e'n hollbwysig iawn.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: place on October 24th and was called to order by myself at 645.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Present were Erinda Benedetto, Kathy Kreatz, Mia Mastone, Robert Scurry, and myself.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Five school committee members present, two absent.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Also present was Superintendent Belson, Headmaster Perella, Vocational Principal Director Heidi Riccio, Director of Buildings and Grounds John McLaughlin, and parent Cheryl Rodriguez.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: After saluting the flag,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And after the purpose of the meeting was stated, which was to review the high school vocational school elements of the proposed capital plan and to do a selected tour of the facility, I called on Superintendent Belson for an overview of the evening's meeting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The superintendent handed out additional copies of the capital plan and a prepared document proposal from the vocational school, which is attached to this report.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The superintendent stated that it would not be possible to view the entire high school

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: or vocational school in one evening, but that the headmaster and vocational principal, along with Director McLaughlin, would identify priority sites for viewing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The topic of overall technology upgrades would be referred to a subsequent session, since this was a major topic with system-wide implications.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Major systems like the roof and HVAC must be part of our overall planning as well.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We have done a roof study and will have a recommendation in the near future.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The superintendent then explained that capital planning must be focused on major projects,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: general maintenance upgrades for the most part belonging in an enhanced operational budget.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Also, that school system capital needs would be part of a larger citywide initiative.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Further, it is important that we view capital plan issues not only as upgrades to facilities, but also as part of a long-term vision for the development of school system capacity and educational opportunities.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: He went on to say, as we recapture certain

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Out of district payments, we must reinvest into our programs in a strategic manner and anticipate the future, not just to upgrade the present facility bit by bit.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Committee members recognized the capital mission, but wanted the administration to plan for greater maintenance investment going forward.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The committee then began a tour of selected sites led by headmaster and vocational principal director and buildings and grounds director.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: First, we went to the library.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Dr. Perella focused on the ways the library has been altered from its original design over the past 45 years.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: He noted that natural lighting has been lost to the addition of several office spaces and also that the general condition of the library has deteriorated.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It would be his plan to redesign the library into an open space media center reflecting upon the advance of technology.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The library would flow into the courtyard and be a multipurpose epicenter for students and faculty exploration and utilization.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: He explained that the initial design and planning had already begun as a result of the XQ Project Academy of the Possible.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The tour of the library ended with an agreement to formalize the design by utilizing the expertise of an architect engineer.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The next tour moved to the vocational school.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Director Riccio explained that her number one priority was the relocation of the culinary arts

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and hospitality program to an accessible location for the general public.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The director reviewed the draft floor plan and explained how the current programs would be moved.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Medford will pursue a state capital skills grant, but it will require matching funds for construction.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This would include gas and water lines, electricity, flooring, lighting, doors, ADA accessibility.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This grant is now being released by the Commonwealth with applications due in December.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The total revamp of the vocational school beyond the culinary arts hospitality project will involve the development of an academy model that groups the various offerings into like clusters.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Long-term development should be pursued in conjunction with MSBA to the extent possible under their priorities and guidelines.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The committee then reconvened in the conference room to recap their tour.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The superintendent indicated that it will be necessary to consider the relocation of certain programs such as early childhood,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and office space to free up areas for program development.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The committee will await follow-up materials to continue its capital planning for the complex.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The meeting was adjourned at 8.45 p.m.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And if I could just add, the tour and the vision that we were presented with at the

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: was truly inspirational and very exciting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And you take the step back and you realize you're not just looking at the smaller pieces of maintenance, which of course are extremely necessary, but kind of a bigger vision and a plan into the future.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you very much, Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Van der Kloot.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yeah.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Van der Kloot.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Madam Mayor, myself and school committee member Kathy Kreatz were able to attend the wonderful mock presidential debate and it was so much fun and our students just did such a great job.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They did a particularly good job in really trying to develop

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: really some understanding of what the candidates were putting forth for policy, which, as we all know, has sometimes been difficult this year.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So, anyway, it was just, knock your socks off, great.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Oh, well, the personas were just stunning.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But in the same handout, I just wanted to bring attention that the media students at MHS have developed a special video which takes a stand against domestic violence.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and because October was Domestic Violence Awareness Month.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. Jack Dempsey, the media teacher, submitted a copy to the video to the MIAA, and though we didn't win this year, but remember we won last year, so someone else has to have a turn, they were so impressed with it, and that it's going to be used, be presented,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: for their wellness educators workshop being held on December 5th.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Prior to the meeting tonight, I took a minute to go online and take a look at it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It is just great.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And it was just, it was really, it just really pulled at you emotionally.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And it's simple, it's direct, it's just wonderful.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Hi.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We did have a meeting on October 13th.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I was the chair.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Subcommittee members Mia Mastone and Robert Scurry were present.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Also present was Kathy Kreatz and Arenda Benedetto, the superintendent, assistant superintendent Diane Caldwell, director of curriculum, Bernadette Riccidelli, director of humanities, Nicole Chiesa,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Director of Math, Carolyn Joy.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Director of Science, Rocco Sieri.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Director of Pupil Services, Kathleen Madaglio.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Director of ELL, Leslie Trotta.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: All of our principals, teachers, Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Cole Sanford, and parents, Alexandra Laurie, Alicia Karen, Melanie McLaughlin, Michelle Ciccolo, and Jen Lewis.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The purpose of the meeting was to review and discuss the 2000 state test results.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We were each provided with the reports on the test results in all areas which are attached to this report.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Deputy Nelson and Assistant Superintendent Caldwell discussed the state testing and the variables affecting the testing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They explained that the discussion would focus on subgroup data for park rates 3 to 8 and MCAS.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Deputy Superintendent introduced Nicole Chiesa, Caroline Joy, and Rocky Cieri.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Caldwell gave a brief history of MCAS.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It was also stated there was no state data available this year.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Vi har en overview av ELA MCAS grad 10 result.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Superintendent Belson clarified the Asian subgroup population.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It is not homogeneous.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It includes a wide range of groups from across the continent, and it varies from city to city.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We continued with an overview of the MCAS grade 10 results, and then we went to the science results for grades 5, 8, and 10.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Discussion was held about the difficulty of disaggregating grade 10 science as students were taking different content areas and are in different grade levels.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They also discussed the low scores for grade 5.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. Cieri said that grade 5 scores were low across the board and he plans research programs this year.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: They also need to look at the budget for material supplies and additional professional development for elementary students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A view of PARC ELA Mathematics for Grades 3 to 8, PARC N to ELA Mathematics for Grades 3 to 8 followed with a review of the highlights and the subgroup data.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Discussion was held regarding computer-based testing at the Andrew School and paper testing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It was determined that more time is needed for elementary staff to learn how to use computers when testing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Dr. Riccadeli explained the PARC assessments.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is Medford's first year.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Students are required to not only answer the question, but also to explain how they got there.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. Benedetto asked about comparison of like districts to Medford.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A report will be generated.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Nelson described the five-point scale park uses and the four-point MCAS scale.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Nelson also reviewed student report inconsistencies around the following changes in numbers between levels, plus or minus

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: 7.4 range and the explanation of the legend.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I asked what was the takeaway from the evening.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Superintendent Belson said that we need to get better, improve science and math scores, review and purchase a new elementary science program.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: and look hard at our specialized population.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There's a lot of transition statewide, and the state is still sorting it out.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mastone would like to look at the Brooks School to collaborate on effective teaching strategies around science.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The number of ELL students at the Brooks is much less than the other schools.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Testing in 2017 was discussed.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The high school will continue to use MCAS.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: MKS 2.0 is untimed, no long compositions, and will resemble park questions.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Grades 4 and 8 will have online testing of all students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The Andrews will be online testing for all grades.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: A meeting with Revere and Burlington Public Schools is planned to look at infrastructure needs for technology.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: McLaughlin raised concerns around students with disabilities taking MCAS 2.0.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It will be discussed in the weeks ahead.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Our meeting was adjourned at 9 p.m.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Respectfully submitted myself as chair.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think committee of the whole is the way to go initially.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But then some people aren't really voting members versus whatever, so I think by starting

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: this with a committee of the whole makes a lot of sense, and then perhaps we can move to decide whether a subcommittee makes a lot of sense.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's a lot of information.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I think everybody's interested.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: That's one of the things, is we're all interested.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We decided to extend it to the end of October.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's very exciting.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's great.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: There is a question about is this consistent with our goals, educational goals.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We have great people and great support, including helping everything work, so I really appreciate that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Van der Kloot.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. Superintendent, I'm wondering if there's any way that we can advocate for that a five-year graduation rate also be included.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: but we have had, as well as many other school systems, additional students who might take a little bit more time, but they do reach the goal.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I'm wondering if, it mentions the high school graduation rates will still be, you know, part of this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: at the state and federal level.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think we can do so in one or two sentences.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Is there a way that we should amend this resolution so that it covers our concern?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm just looking as I read it, having heard your point.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So there's obviously many, many different levels of conversation that we could have on this.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I'm going to strictly take mine to the financial.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Right now, it costs Medford approximately $4 million to fund our charter school students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We have 10 students less than last year, but it's costing us $270,000 more this year.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Why is that?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's because the state has underfunded the charter school account by $57 million.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This comes to one of those unfunded mandates.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's not a question of how good charter schools are or how not.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Right now we're simply talking about a funding mechanism and the number of charter schools that would be potentially approved by this would only have a greater impact.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Therefore, I certainly personally have been urging people to vote no on two because of the particular way the funding works.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I would urge the school committee to take a stand and say vote no on two.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Sure.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And we have to worry about them.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I am a little concerned.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: to that.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: The only problem with doing that is that we have ELL students then who have been at the Roberts for the younger grades, who have friendships, who are comfortable there.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And now we're, you know.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Yeah, but they would be moved out of that comfort.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But anyway, it's almost secondary.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Mr. Superintendent, I just have to say I disagree respectfully with you a little bit.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I don't think that the urge here is to up it.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I do think that all the school committee members heard

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: that events happened last week and parents weren't notified.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And I, too, was looking for unity because that is what we want to go into and support.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I do understand that people might have preferences, and I'm sure, for example, that many of my colleagues would, in fact, like to have

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: said we're going to do kindergarten aides across the city all at once.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: This is a very large budget with many other things, very important things to us.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We've added an English teacher.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We've added lots of different elements.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I think that the committee has spoken and said, yes, there is a desire in the future to add that we're starting out with the Roberts.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: It's a level three school.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: justification for why we're starting in this particular school.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I hasten to remind everybody that when we get to kindergarten aids, the money, the dollars seem short, but the obligation of the city in terms of the additional finances for healthcare are significant.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I think that the beginnings of this budget and on that particular issue have been addressed, and it's clearly been heard that there is a desire to increase as we go on.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I share with the superintendent frustration.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I know the other night,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I had hoped to have a unified budget, and there were some levels of consternation because there were so many things that weren't clear, and tonight we've now clarified those in, I think, a very, very positive manner.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I for one would ask my colleagues to reconsider their vote, and I would like to have a discussion and see, because I'm not quite sure if that's the only issue that's outstanding, and I'm not understanding something else for that negative vote by my colleagues, that I would urge you to reconsider, because a budget is a huge

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Entity, it is not a one issue question.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: We are here for the good of all of our students, whether they're in kindergarten or whether they're in a high school senior.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Every student is important.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And to hold up that unity on a budget because of one issue, especially when so much progress has been made, I believe is not in the best interest of the public schools and the children and families we serve.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Madam Mayor, I wouldn't want anyone to think that we couldn't vote, certainly as we did.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: And it's just that, quite honestly, I was surprised.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I want to make it clear, by the way, that there have been years where I have voted against the budget because I was concerned

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: that the entire budget level was short, and that we were not meeting the needs of our students.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So please understand that it's not, that I've never, that I've always been in agreement with the bottom line, but that's really the issue.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: In some ways, it's the ultimate bottom line.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I didn't understand why my colleagues voted against it, and that's why I said what I said.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: I am wondering, since the superintendent has made a statement sort of saying, geez, I'd rather go in with a unified force,

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: whether there was a point in my asking for reconsideration so that we could vote it again if any colleague had a feeling that they were persuaded for some sense of unity.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: But if there's not, then I respect your votes, and I'm not going to bother for a reconsideration.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So I was just trying to sort of feel out whether either of my colleagues who voted against the budget wanted to reconsider their thoughts.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: If you're willing.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So, Madam Mayor, just to conclude the discussion, then, I certainly want to express to my two colleagues that I appreciate their due diligence, and I respect their votes, even if I disagree with it and would have preferred it a different way.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: However, even though, Erin, you've asked many questions, and I can know some of your areas of concern, I still was surprised, because I thought we were more on the same page.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Now that you've articulated exactly where you're coming from, I appreciate it, I understand it, and I now understand the vote better.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: So thank you and we'll, if we could, did we call the vote?

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: No.

[Paulette Van der Kloot]: Called the vote.
